--Word--|rabblement |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Derogatory. A class or category of people conceived of as forming a mob; = rabble. Frequently with of. Also in figurative context and extended use. Now rare.|A disorderly, disorganized, or unruly crowd; = rabble. Frequently with of. Now chiefly literal or Scottish and English regional (northern).|With the. The socially inferior, uncouth, or disorderly element of the populace or of a particular group or body of people; also without article.|Confusion, disturbance, or disorder such as that caused by a rabble or unruly crowd; riotous conduct; uproar.|A disorderly or disorganized collection; = rabble 4b. Frequently with of. In later use chiefly poetic and rare.|--Examples--|

--Word--|race |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A competition between runners, horses, vehicles, etc. to see which is the fastest in covering a set course.|A series of races for horses or dogs, held at a fixed time on a set course.|A situation in which individuals or groups compete to be first to achieve a particular objective.|The course of the sun or moon through the heavens.|A strong or rapid current flowing through a narrow channel in the sea or a river.|A water channel, especially one built to lead water to or from a point where its energy is utilized, as in a mill or mine.|A smooth ring-shaped groove or guide in which a ball bearing or roller bearing runs.|A fenced passageway in a stockyard through which animals pass singly for branding, loading, washing, etc.|(in weaving) the channel along which the shuttle moves.|Compete with another or others to see who is fastest at covering a set course or achieving an objective.|Compete regularly in races as a sport or leisure activity.|Prepare and enter (an animal or vehicle) for races.|Move or progress swiftly or at full speed.|Operate or cause to operate at excessive speed.|(of a person's heart or pulse) beat faster than usual because of fear or excitement.|--Examples--|Hill started from pole position and won the race|the race for nuclear power|the industrious sun already half his race hath run|angling for tuna in turbulent tidal races|the vet took blood samples from the horses before they raced|two drivers raced each other through a housing estate|next year, he raced again for the team|he raced his three horses simply for the fun of it|I raced into the house|she spoke automatically, while her mind raced ahead|the truck came to rest against a tree with its engine racing|

--Word--|race |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A competition between runners, horses, vehicles, etc. to see which is the fastest in covering a set course.|A series of races for horses or dogs, held at a fixed time on a set course.|A situation in which individuals or groups compete to be first to achieve a particular objective.|The course of the sun or moon through the heavens.|A strong or rapid current flowing through a narrow channel in the sea or a river.|A water channel, especially one built to lead water to or from a point where its energy is utilized, as in a mill or mine.|A smooth ring-shaped groove or guide in which a ball bearing or roller bearing runs.|A fenced passageway in a stockyard through which animals pass singly for branding, loading, washing, etc.|(in weaving) the channel along which the shuttle moves.|Compete with another or others to see who is fastest at covering a set course or achieving an objective.|Compete regularly in races as a sport or leisure activity.|Prepare and enter (an animal or vehicle) for races.|Move or progress swiftly or at full speed.|Operate or cause to operate at excessive speed.|(of a person's heart or pulse) beat faster than usual because of fear or excitement.|--Examples--|Hill started from pole position and won the race|the race for nuclear power|the industrious sun already half his race hath run|angling for tuna in turbulent tidal races|the vet took blood samples from the horses before they raced|two drivers raced each other through a housing estate|next year, he raced again for the team|he raced his three horses simply for the fun of it|I raced into the house|she spoke automatically, while her mind raced ahead|the truck came to rest against a tree with its engine racing|

--Word--|rackett |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A double-reed woodwind instrument of the Renaissance and Baroque periods, with a squat cylindrical body in which nine parallel bores are drilled lengthwise to form a continuous undulating tube. Sometimes with preceding modifying word, indicating the size or pitch of the instrument, as bass rackett, tenor rackett, etc.|Originally and usually rankett. An organ stop of the regal type, with short resonators and a soft tone, originally popular in the 16th cent., but now little used.|--Examples--|

--Word--|radiant |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Sending out light; shining or glowing brightly.|(of a person or their expression) clearly emanating great joy, love, or health.|(of an emotion or quality) emanating powerfully from someone or something; very conspicuous.|(of electromagnetic energy, especially heat) transmitted by radiation, rather than conduction or convection.|(of an appliance) designed to emit radiant energy, especially for cooking or heating.|A point or object from which light or heat radiates, especially a heating element in an electric or gas heater.|A radiant point.|--Examples--|a bird with radiant green and red plumage|she gave him a radiant smile|he praised her radiant self-confidence|plants convert the radiant energy of the sun into chemical energy|a radiant heater|I sat down by my hissing gas fire—one of the radiants was missing|don't assume that you should stare toward the radiant to see the most meteors|

--Word--|radiata |--Type--|noun, noun|--Meanings--|Treated as plural. A major group of animals containing invertebrates whose body plan shows a radial structure: (originally) a division including coelenterates, echinoderms, and various intestinal and other worms (now historical); (now) a group comprising the cnidarians and ctenophores. (Also in form radiata) animals of this group (collectively or individually).|In full radiata pine. = Monterey pine.|--Examples--|

--Word--|radical |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|(especially of change or action) relating to or affecting the fundamental nature of something; far-reaching or thorough.|Forming an inherent or fundamental part of the nature of someone or something.|(of surgery or medical treatment) thorough and intended to be completely curative.|Advocating or based on thorough or complete political or social change; representing or supporting an extreme or progressive section of a political party.|Belonging to an extreme section of the Liberal party during the 19th century.|Characterized by independence of or departure from tradition; innovative or unorthodox.|Denoting or relating to the roots of a word.|Belonging to the root of a chord.|Relating to or forming the root of a number or quantity.|Of, or springing direct from, the root or stem base of a plant.|Very good; excellent.|A person who advocates thorough or complete political or social change, or a member of a political party or section of a party pursuing such aims.|A group of atoms behaving as a unit in a number of compounds.|The root or base form of a word.|Any of the basic set of approximately 214 Chinese characters constituting semantically or functionally significant elements in the composition of other characters and used as a means of classifying characters in dictionaries.|A quantity forming or expressed as the root of another.|A radical sign.|--Examples--|a radical overhaul of the existing regulatory framework|the assumption of radical differences between the mental attributes of literate and non-literate peoples|a radical American activist|the daring, avant-garde spirit of the music was too radical for the conservative audience|Okay, then. --Word--|radical |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|(especially of change or action) relating to or affecting the fundamental nature of something; far-reaching or thorough.|Forming an inherent or fundamental part of the nature of someone or something.|(of surgery or medical treatment) thorough and intended to be completely curative.|Advocating or based on thorough or complete political or social change; representing or supporting an extreme or progressive section of a political party.|Belonging to an extreme section of the Liberal party during the 19th century.|Characterized by independence of or departure from tradition; innovative or unorthodox.|Denoting or relating to the roots of a word.|Belonging to the root of a chord.|Relating to or forming the root of a number or quantity.|Of, or springing direct from, the root or stem base of a plant.|Very good; excellent.|A person who advocates thorough or complete political or social change, or a member of a political party or section of a party pursuing such aims.|A group of atoms behaving as a unit in a number of compounds.|The root or base form of a word.|Any of the basic set of approximately 214 Chinese characters constituting semantically or functionally significant elements in the composition of other characters and used as a means of classifying characters in dictionaries.|A quantity forming or expressed as the root of another.|A radical sign.|--Examples--|a radical overhaul of the existing regulatory framework|the assumption of radical differences between the mental attributes of literate and non-literate peoples|a radical American activist|the daring, avant-garde spirit of the music was too radical for the conservative audience|Okay, then. Seven o'clock. Radical!|

--Word--|rage |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|Violent uncontrollable anger.|Anger or aggression associated with conflict arising from a particular situation.|The violent action of a natural agency.|A vehement desire or passion.|A widespread temporary enthusiasm or fashion.|Prophetic, poetic, or martial enthusiasm or ardour.|A lively party.|Feel or express violent uncontrollable anger.|Continue with great force or intensity.|(of an illness or fire) spread very rapidly or uncontrollably.|(of an emotion) have or reach a high degree of intensity.|Enjoy oneself at a party or other lively gathering, typically with drinking and music.|--Examples--|her face was distorted with rage|he flew into a rage|office rage is on the increase|the rising rage of the sea|a rage for absolute honesty informs much western art|computer games are all the rage|Leaden Age, Quicken'd with Youthfull Spleene, and Warlike Rage|the sound of the rage filled the campus|he raged at the futility of it all|That's unfair! Maggie raged|the argument raged for days|the children had to seek shelter while the storm raged|at 3 a.m., the party was still raging|the great cholera epidemic which raged across Europe in 1831|she couldn't hide the fear that raged within her|we're gonna rage through the weekend|

--Word--|rift sawing |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(Originally) = quarter sawing; (now also North American) a method of sawing a log of wood into boards by quartering the log radially and making further cuts aligned to the centre of the tree and parallel to each other, producing boards with a uniform and straight grain pattern.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Massey, Raymond |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1896–1983), US actor and producer; born in Canada; full name Raymond Hart Massey. --Word--|Popper, Sir Karl Raimund |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1902–94), Austrian-born British philosopher. In The Logic of Scientific Discovery (1934) he argued that scientific hypotheses can never be finally confirmed as true, but are tested by attempts to falsify them. In The Open Society and its Enemies (1945) he criticized the historicist social theories of Plato, Hegel, and Marx.|--Examples--|

wings.|An area allocated to a police officer and patrolled on foot.|A spell of duty allocated to a police officer.|An area regularly frequented by someone.|A person's area of interest.|A stretch of water fished by an angler.|A brief pause or moment of hesitation.|Completely exhausted.|Relating to the beat generation or its philosophy.|--Examples--|if we were caught we were beaten|the victims were beaten to death with baseball bats|they beat me with a stick and punched me|he beat the table with his hand|drums were beating in the distance|upright cleaners have a motorized head which beats the carpet to loosen the dirt|pure gold can be beaten out to form very thin sheets|she beat her fists against the wood|Sidney beat on the door with the flat of his hand|Emmie began to beat at the flames|they hire boys to beat the Yorkshire moors for game birds|she beat him easily at chess|Juventus were beaten 2–1|the battle to beat car crime|he beat heroin addiction in 1992|he beat his own world record|you can't beat the taste of fresh raspberries|it beats me how you manage to work in this heat|the defender beat him to the ball|they set off early to beat the traffic|her heart beat faster with panic|doves wheel around the rooftops, beating their wings|an owl beat low over the salt marsh|beat the butter until light and fluffy|beat the cream into the mixture|now beat it, will you!|we beat southwards all that first day|the glissando begins on the second beat|the music changed to a funky disco beat|the beat of the wipers became almost hypnotic|he heard a regular drum beat|the beat of the swallow's wings as they dive after midges|his beat was in North London|it's important to have cops on the beat|his beat ended at 6 a.m|a few, new to their beat, looked at him with interest|his beat is construction, property, and hotels|you don't necessarily have to fish on the priciest beats to find good sport|she waited for a beat of three seconds|I'm beat—I need an hour or so to rest|beat poet Allen Ginsberg|

--Word--|rainbow |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An arch of colours visible in the sky, caused by the refraction and dispersion of the sun's light by rain or other water droplets in the atmosphere. The colours of the rainbow are generally said to be red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet.|A display of the colours of the spectrum produced by dispersion of light.|A wide range of related and typically colourful things.|Many-coloured.|--Examples--|all the colours of the rainbow|a rainbow of medals decorated his chest|a big rainbow packet of felt pens|

--Word--|rainbow |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An arch of colours visible in the sky, caused by the refraction and dispersion of the sun's light by rain or other water droplets in the atmosphere. The colours of the rainbow are generally said to be red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet.|A display of the colours of the spectrum produced by dispersion of light.|A wide range of related and typically colourful things.|Many-coloured.|--Examples--|all the colours of the rainbow|a rainbow of medals decorated his chest|a big rainbow packet of felt pens|

--Word--|ray |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|Each of the lines in which light (and heat) may seem to stream from the sun or any luminous body, or pass through a small opening.|The straight line in which light or other electromagnetic radiation travels to a given point.|A specified form of non-luminous radiation.|Sunlight considered in the context of sunbathing.|An initial or slight indication of a positive or welcome quality in a time of difficulty or trouble.|Any of a set of straight lines passing through one point.|A thing that is arranged radially.|Any of the individual strap-shaped florets around the edge of the flower of a daisy or related plant.|Each of the long slender bony supports in the fins of most bony fishes.|Each radial arm of a starfish.|Spread from or as if from a central point.|Radiate (light)|--Examples--|a ray of sunlight came through the window|take a specific point and back-trace every ray of light that hits that point|ultraviolet rays|catch some rays on a sandy beach|if only I could see some ray of hope|the ray that runs from the centre of the circle to the point of tangency|delicate lines rayed out at each corner of her eyes|the sun rays forth its natural light into the air|

--Word--|raise |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Lift or move to a higher position or level.|Lift or move to a vertical position; set upright.|Construct or build (a structure)|Cause to rise or form.|Bring to the surface (a ship that has sunk)|Cause (bread) to rise, especially by the action of yeast.|Make (a nap) on cloth.|Increase the amount, level, or strength of.|Promote (someone) to a higher rank.|(in transformational grammar) move (a noun phrase) out of a subordinate clause and into a main clause under certain conditions.|Multiply a quantity to (a specified power)|(in poker or brag) bet (a specified amount) more than (another player)|Make a higher bid in the same suit as that bid by (one's partner)|Cause to occur or to be considered.|Generate (an invoice or other document)|Collect, levy, or bring together (money or resources)|Bring up (a child)|Breed or grow (animals or plants)|Bring (someone) back from death.|Cause (a ghost or spirit) to appear.|Abandon or force an enemy to abandon (a siege, blockade, or embargo)|Drive (an animal) from its lair.|(of someone at sea) come in sight of (land or another ship)|Establish contact with (someone) by telephone or radio.|Stimulate production of (an antiserum, antibody, or other biologically active substance) against the appropriate target cell or substance.|An increase in salary.|(in poker or brag) an increase in a stake.|A higher bid in the suit that one's partner has bid.|An act of lifting or raising a part of the body while holding a weight.|--Examples--|she raised both arms above her head|his flag was raised over the city|Melody managed to raise him to his feet|a fence was being raised around the property|the galloping horse raised a cloud of dust|divers have located and hope to raise the submarine|a strain of yeast that would create enough gas to raise the thick bread dough|the gig mills raised the nap on the cloth prior to shearing|the bank raised interest rates|the need to raise the quality of education|he had to raise his voice to make himself heard|the king raised him to the title of Count Torre Bella|3 raised to the 7th power is 2,187|I'll raise you another hundred dollars|with support for partner's bid suit you raise him to game in it|North raises to three no trumps|the alarm was raised when he failed to return home|universities are meant to raise doubts about every axiom|I have raised an invoice for the tape|it is hoped that the event will raise £50,000|he was born and raised in San Francisco|they raised pigs and kept a pony|God raised Jesus from the dead|the piece raises the ghosts of a number of twentieth-century ideas|in late April Henry decided to raise the siege|the rabbit was only 250 yards from where he first raised it|they raised the low coast by evening|I raised him on the open line|monoclonal antibodies raised against human lymphocytes|he wants a raise and some perks|bent-over raises|

in a stake.|A higher bid in the suit that one's partner has bid.|An act of lifting or raising a part of the body while holding a weight.|--Examples--|she raised both arms above her head|his flag was submarine|a strain of yeast that would create enough gas to raise the thick bread dough|the gig mills raised the nap on the cloth prior to shearing|the bank raised interest rates|the need to raise the --Word--|Raleigh, Sir Walter |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(c.1552–1618), English explorer, courtier, and writer. A favourite of Elizabeth I, he organized several voyages of exploration and colonization to the Americas, and introduced potato and tobacco plants to England. Imprisoned in 1603 by James I on a charge of conspiracy, he was released in 1616 to lead an expedition in search of El Dorado, but was executed on the original charge when he returned empty-handed.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rally |--Type--|verb, noun, verb|--Meanings--|(of troops) come together again in order to continue fighting after a defeat or dispersion.|Bring together (forces) again in order to continue fighting.|Assemble in a mass meeting.|Bring or come together in order to support a person or cause.|Recover or cause to recover in health, spirits, or poise.|(of share, currency, or commodity prices) increase after a fall.|Drive in a rally.|A mass meeting of people making a political protest or showing support for a cause.|An open-air event for people who own a particular kind of vehicle.|A long-distance race for motor vehicles over public roads or rough terrain, typically in several stages.|A quick or marked recovery after a decline.|(in tennis and other racket sports) an extended exchange of strokes between players.|Subject (someone) to good-humoured ridicule; tease.|--Examples--|De Montfort's troops rallied and drove back the king's infantry|the king escaped to Perth to rally his own forces|up to 50,000 people rallied in the city centre|colleagues rallied round to help Ann|a series of meetings to rally support for the union|he floundered for a moment, then rallied again|they rallied her with a drink|prices of metals have rallied|we're driving off to Spain to rally|he has raced and rallied MGBs for thirty years|a banned nationalist rally|a traction engine rally|a rally driver|the market staged a late rally|a rally of more than three strokes was a rarity|he rallied her on the length of her pigtail|

--Word--|Ramses |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|The name of eleven Egyptian pharaohs.|Ramses II (died c.1225 BC), reigned c.1292–c.1225 BC; known as Ramses the Great. The third pharaoh of the 19th dynasty, he built vast monuments and statues, including the two rock temples at Abu Simbel.|Ramses III (died c.1167 BC), reigned c.1198–c.1167 BC. The second pharaoh of the 20th dynasty, he fought decisive battles against the Libyans and the Sea Peoples. After his death the power of Egypt declined.|--Examples--|

--Word--|ramp |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A sloping surface joining two different levels, as at the entrance or between floors of a building.|A movable set of steps for entering or leaving an aircraft.|A transverse ridge in a road to control the speed of vehicles.|An inclined slip road leading on to or off a main road or motorway.|An upward bend in a stair rail.|An electrical waveform in which the voltage increases or decreases linearly with time.|A swindle, especially one involving a fraudulent increase of the price of a share.|Increase the level or amount of (something) sharply.|Drive up the price of (a company's shares) in order to gain a financial advantage.|(of an animal) rear up on its hind legs in a threatening posture.|Rush about uncontrollably.|(of a plant) grow or climb luxuriantly.|(of an electrical waveform) increase or decrease voltage linearly with time.|Provide with a ramp.|--Examples--|a wheelchair ramp|an exit ramp|a voltage ramp|the Stock Exchange is investigating two blatant share ramps|the company has moved into new quarters in order to ramp up production|the level of violence is ramping up|a rule against share price ramping which forbids a broker to account for more than 30 per cent of trading in a share|they roared and ramped in cages|a ramping lion|an awful beast ramping about the woods and fields|ivy ramped over the flower beds|the integrated circuit's output then ramps in the negative direction|ramped access to public buildings|

--Word--|ramp |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A sloping surface joining two different levels, as at the entrance or between floors of a building.|A movable set of steps for entering or leaving an aircraft.|A transverse ridge in a road to control the speed of vehicles.|An inclined slip road leading on to or off a main road or motorway.|An upward bend in a stair rail.|An electrical waveform in which the voltage increases or decreases linearly with time.|A swindle, especially one involving a fraudulent increase of the price of a share.|Increase the level or amount of (something) sharply.|Drive up the price of (a company's shares) in order to gain a financial advantage.|(of an animal) rear up on its hind legs in a threatening posture.|Rush about uncontrollably.|(of a plant) grow or climb luxuriantly.|(of an electrical waveform) increase or decrease voltage linearly with time.|Provide with a ramp.|--Examples--|a wheelchair ramp|an exit ramp|a voltage ramp|the Stock Exchange is investigating two blatant share ramps|the company has moved into new quarters in order to ramp up production|the level of violence is ramping up|a rule against share price ramping which forbids a broker to account for more than 30 per cent of trading in a share|they roared and ramped in cages|a ramping lion|an awful beast ramping about the woods and fields|ivy ramped over the flower beds|the integrated circuit's output then ramps in the negative direction|ramped access to public buildings|

--Word--|range |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|The area of variation between upper and lower limits on a particular scale.|The scope of a person's knowledge or abilities.|The compass of a person's voice or a musical instrument.|The period of time covered by something such as a forecast.|The area covered by or included in something.|The set of values that a given function can take as its argument varies.|A set of different things of the same general type.|The distance within which a person can see or hear.|The maximum distance to which a gun will shoot or over which a missile will travel.|The maximum distance at which a radio transmission can be effectively received.|The distance that can be covered by a vehicle or aircraft without refuelling.|The distance between a camera and the subject to be photographed.|A line or series of mountains or hills.|Mountainous or hilly country.|A large area of open land for grazing or hunting.|An area of land or sea used as a testing ground for military equipment.|An open or enclosed area with targets for shooting practice.|The area over which a plant or animal is distributed.|A large cooking stove with burners or hotplates and one or more ovens, all of which are kept continually hot.|An electric or gas cooker.|A row of buildings.|A continuous stretch of a building.|The direction or position in which something lies.|(of a person or their lifestyle) orderly; settled.|--Examples--|the cost will be in the range of $1–5 million a day|grand hotels were outside my price range|in this film he gave some indication of his range|she was gifted with an incredible vocal range|a guide to the range of debate this issue has generated|the area offers a wide range of activities for the tourist|the company's new carpet range|something lurked just beyond her range of vision|these rockets have a range of 30 to 40 miles|a duck came within range|planets within radio range of Earth|the vans have a range of 125 miles|handheld shots taken at extreme telephoto ranges can be pretty wobbly affairs|a mountain range|no one would know if he had survived to live out his life in the ranges back from the river country|on dude ranches, tourists put on crisp new western gear to ride the range|the cost of dealing with unexploded shells and bombs on former military ranges|he went down to the ranges to practise shooting|the chimpanzee extensively overlaps the gorilla in its forest range|a wood-burning kitchen range|Townesend's Durham quadrangle range at Trinity College|the range of the hills and valleys is nearly from north to south|it's possible to be too rangé|by comparison with Strachey, Keynes was rangé|

--Word--|Rangoon |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|The former capital of Burma (Myanmar), a port in the Irrawaddy delta; population 4,088,000 (est. 2007). For centuries a Buddhist religious centre, it is the site of the Shwe Dagon Pagoda, built over 2,500 years ago. The modern city was established by the British in the mid 19th century and was the capital from 1886 until it was replaced by Naypyidaw in 2005.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ranjit Singh |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1780–1839), Indian maharaja, founder of the Sikh state of Punjab; known as the Lion of the Punjab. He proclaimed himself maharaja of Punjab in 1801, and went on to make it the most powerful state in India. Most of his territory was annexed by Britain after the Sikh Wars which followed his death.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rank |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A position in the hierarchy of the armed forces.|A position within the hierarchy of an organization or society.|High social position.|A number specifying position in a numerically ordered series.|(in systemic grammar) the level of a linguistic unit or set of linguistic units in relation to other sets in the hierarchy.|A single line of soldiers or police officers drawn up abreast.|A regular row or line of things or people.|Each of the eight rows of eight squares running from side to side across a chessboard.|The people belonging to or constituting a group or class.|(in the armed forces) those who are not commissioned officers.|The value or the order of the largest non-zero determinant of a given matrix.|An analogous quantity in other kinds of group.|Give (someone or something) a rank or place within a grading system.|Have a specified rank or place within a grading system.|Take precedence over (someone) in respect of rank; outrank.|Arrange in a row or rows.|--Examples--|an army officer of high rank|he was promoted to the rank of Captain|only two cabinet members had held ministerial rank before|persons of rank and breeding|they were drawn up outside their barracks in long ranks|conifer plantations growing in serried ranks|the ranks of Britain's unemployed|he was fined and reduced to the ranks|students ranked the samples in order of preference|she is ranked number four in the world|he now ranks third in America|the Secretary of State ranks all the other members of the cabinet|the tents were ranked in orderly rows|

--Word--|rackett |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A double-reed woodwind instrument of the Renaissance and Baroque periods, with a squat cylindrical body in which nine parallel bores are drilled lengthwise to form a continuous undulating tube. Sometimes with preceding modifying word, indicating the size or pitch of the instrument, as bass rackett, tenor rackett, etc.|Originally and usually rankett. An organ stop of the regal type, with short resonators and a soft tone, originally popular in the 16th cent., but now little used.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rackett |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A double-reed woodwind instrument of the Renaissance and Baroque periods, with a squat cylindrical body in which nine parallel bores are drilled lengthwise to form a continuous undulating tube. --Word--|ran-tan |--Type--|verb, exclamation|--Meanings--|English regional (northern and midlands). To condemn and humiliate (a husband) publicly for beating his wife, typically by causing a disturbance outside his house by beating pots and kettles, singing and chanting loudly, etc., and sometimes also by beating him, chasing him from the town, or compelling him to ride the stang. Also occasionally without object. Now historical.|Representing a loud and repetitive banging noise, especially that made by knocking or drumming.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rap |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Strike (a hard surface) with a series of rapid audible blows, especially in order to attract attention.|Strike (something) several times against a hard surface.|Strike sharply with a stick or similar implement.|Criticize severely.|Say sharply or suddenly.|Talk or chat in an easy and familiar manner.|Perform rap music.|A quick, sharp knock or blow.|A sharp criticism.|A type of popular music of US black origin in which words are recited rapidly and rhythmically over an instrumental backing.|A piece of rap, or the words themselves.|A lengthy or impromptu conversation.|A criminal charge, especially of a specified kind.|A person's reputation, typically a bad one.|--Examples--|he stood up and rapped the table|she rapped on the window|she rapped her stick on the floor|she rapped my fingers with a ruler|certain banks are to be rapped for delaying interest rate cuts|the ambassador rapped out an order|we could be here all night rapping about spiritualism|he raps under the name of Mr T|there was a confident rap at the door|social services were smarting from an Ombudsman's rap|the label specializes in rap and modern soul|rap artists|the track's a surprisingly lyrical rap|dropping in after work for a rap over a beer|he's just been acquitted on a murder rap|why should drag queens get a bad rap?|

--Word--|Raphia |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Originally: the palm Raphia farinifera, which is native to Madagascar and tropical Africa and is a principal source of the fibre raffia. In later use: (in form Raphia) a genus of tropical African and American palms which are noted for their enormous leaves and are a source of fibre, wax, wine, beads, and other products; (also raphia) any palm of this genus.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rape |--Type--|noun, verb, noun, noun, noun|--Meanings--|The crime, typically committed by a man, of forcing another person to have sexual intercourse with the offender against their will.|The abduction of a woman, especially for the purpose of having sexual intercourse with her.|The wanton destruction or spoiling of a place.|(typically of a man) force (another person) to have sexual intercourse with the offender against their will.|Spoil or destroy (a place)|A plant of the cabbage family with bright yellow heavily scented flowers, especially a variety (oilseed rape) grown for its oil-rich seed and as stockfeed.|The stalks and skins of grapes left after winemaking, used in making vinegar.|(in the UK) any of the six ancient divisions of Sussex.|--Examples--|he denied two charges of rape|he had committed at least two rapes|a rape victim|the Rape of the Sabine Women|the rape of the countryside|the woman was raped at knifepoint|he pleaded not guilty to burglary with intent to rape|timber men doubt the government's ability to ensure the forests are not raped|

--Word--|rap |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Strike (a hard surface) with a series of rapid audible blows, especially in order to attract attention.|Strike (something) several times against a hard surface.|Strike sharply with a stick or similar implement.|Criticize severely.|Say sharply or suddenly.|Talk or chat in an easy and familiar manner.|Perform rap music.|A quick, sharp knock or blow.|A sharp criticism.|A type of popular music of US black origin in which words are recited rapidly and rhythmically over an instrumental backing.|A piece of rap, or the words themselves.|A lengthy or impromptu conversation.|A criminal charge, especially of a specified kind.|A person's reputation, typically a bad one.|--Examples--|he stood up and rapped the table|she rapped on the window|she rapped her stick on the floor|she rapped my fingers with a ruler|certain banks are to be rapped for delaying interest rate cuts|the ambassador rapped out an order|we could be here all night rapping about spiritualism|he raps under the name of Mr T|there was a confident rap at the door|social services were smarting from an Ombudsman's rap|the label specializes in rap and modern soul|rap artists|the track's a surprisingly lyrical rap|dropping in after work for a rap over a beer|he's just been acquitted on a murder rap|why should drag queens get a bad rap?|

--Word--|felt |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A kind of cloth made by rolling and pressing wool or another suitable textile accompanied by the application of moisture or heat, which causes the constituent fibres to mat together to create a smooth surface.|Make into felt; mat together.|Become matted.|Cover with felt.|--Examples--|a felt hat|the fibres are shredded and felted together|care must be taken in washing, or the wool will shrink and felt|it wasn't long before we had felted the roof making it totally watertight|

--Word--|rasp |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A harsh, grating noise.|A coarse file or similar metal tool for scraping, filing, or rubbing down objects of metal, wood, or other hard material.|Make a harsh, grating noise.|Say in a harsh, grating voice.|Scrape or file (something) with a rasp.|(of a rough surface or object) scrape in a painful or unpleasant way.|Remove something by scraping it off.|--Examples--|the rasp of the engine|my breath rasped in my throat|Stay where you are! he rasped|the horse has to be sedated for its teeth to be rasped|the bark was deeply grooved, rasping her fingers|more enamel is rasped off the upper outside edges of the teeth|

--Word--|Rasputin, Grigori |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1871–1916), Russian monk; full name Grigori Efimovich Rasputin. He came to exert great influence over Tsar Nicholas II and his family during the First World War; this influence, combined with his reputation for debauchery, steadily discredited the imperial family, and he was assassinated by a group loyal to the tsar.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Rastafarian |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Relating to a religious movement of Jamaican origin holding that Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia was the Messiah and that black people are the chosen people and will eventually return to their African homeland.|A member of the Rastafarian religious movement. Rastafarians have distinctive codes of behaviour and dress, including the wearing of dreadlocks and the smoking of cannabis, and they follow a diet that excludes pork, shellfish, and milk.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rate |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A measure, quantity, or frequency, typically one measured against another quantity or measure.|The speed with which something moves or happens.|A fixed price paid or charged for something.|The amount of a charge or payment expressed as a percentage of another amount, or as a basis of calculation.|(in the UK) a tax on commercial land and buildings paid to a local authority; (in Northern Ireland and formerly in the UK) a tax levied on private property.|Assign a standard or value to (something) according to a particular scale.|Assign a standard, optimal, or limiting rating to (a piece of equipment)|(in the UK) assess the value of (a property) for the purpose of levying a local tax.|Consider to be of a certain quality or standard.|Be regarded in a specified way.|Have a high opinion of.|Be worthy of; merit.|--Examples--|the island has the lowest crime rate in the world|buying up sites at a rate of one a month|the band is shedding vocalists at an alarming rate|your heart rate|a £3.40 minimum hourly rate of pay|advertising rates|you'll find our current interest rate very competitive|they were asked to rate their ability at different driving manoeuvres|the hotel, rated four star, had no hot water|the average life of the new bulb is rated at approximately 500 hours|Atkinson rates him as Europe's top defender|the program has been rated a great success|Jeff still rates as one of the nicest people I have ever met|Mike certainly rated her, goodness knows why|the ambassador rated a bulletproof car and a police escort|

--Word--|ratine |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|In early use (frequently in form ratteen): a kind of coarse twilled woollen fabric, usually with a (curled) nap; a frieze or drugget. Later: (usually in form ratine or ratiné) a plain-woven fabric made of cotton or other material with a loose open weave and rough surface, principally used for hard-wearing outer clothing, furniture covers, etc.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rather |--Type--|adverb, exclamation|--Meanings--|Used to indicate one's preference in a particular matter.|To a certain or significant extent or degree.|Used before verbs so as to make the expression of a feeling or opinion less assertive.|Used to suggest that the opposite of a previous statement is the case; on the contrary.|More precisely.|Instead of; as opposed to.|Used to express emphatic affirmation, agreement, or acceptance.|--Examples--|would you like some wine or would you rather stick to sherry?|she'd rather die than cause a scene|I'd rather you didn't tell him|she's been behaving rather strangely|he's rather an unpleasant man|I rather think he wants me to marry him|we were rather hoping you might do that for us|There is no shortage of basic skills in the workplace. Rather, the problem is poor management|I walked, or rather limped, the two miles home|she seemed indifferent rather than angry|You are glad to be home, aren't you? Rather!|

--Word--|rathite |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Any of a group of minerals that consist of complex sulpharsenites of lead, often with thallium and other elements, and occur in crystalline dolomite in the Binnental in Valais, Switzerland; frequently with distinguishing Roman numeral; specifically (also rathite-I) the first described of these minerals, which occurs as metallic grey crystals of the monoclinic system and is distinguished from dufrénoysite by the presence of thallium, silver, and (sometimes) antimony.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rating |--Type--|noun, noun|--Meanings--|A classification or ranking of someone or something based on a comparative assessment of their quality, standard, or performance.|The estimated audience size of a particular television or radio programme.|The value of a property or condition which is claimed to be standard, optimal, or limiting for a substance, material, or device.|Any of the classes into which racing yachts are assigned according to dimensions.|A non-commissioned sailor in the navy.|An angry reprimand.|--Examples--|the hotel regained its five-star rating|the soap's ratings have recently picked up|fuel with a low octane rating|a masthead boat of similar rating|the rest of the new crew was made up of naval ratings|a servant getting a rating from his master|
--Word--|rating |--Type--|noun, noun|--Meanings--|A classification or ranking of someone or something based on a comparative assessment of their quality, standard, or performance.|The estimated audience size of a particular television or radio programme.|The value of a property or condition which is claimed to be standard, optimal, or limiting for a substance, material, or device.|Any of the classes into which racing yachts are assigned according to dimensions.|A non-commissioned sailor in the navy.|An angry reprimand.|--Examples--|the hotel regained its five-star rating|the soap's ratings have recently picked up|fuel with a low octane rating|a masthead boat of similar rating|the rest of the new crew was made up of naval ratings|a servant getting a rating from his master|

--Word--|ration |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A fixed amount of a commodity officially allowed to each person during a time of shortage, as in wartime.|An amount of food supplied on a regular basis, especially to members of the armed forces during a war.|Food; provisions.|A fixed amount of a particular thing.|Allow each person to have only a fixed amount of (a commodity)|Allow someone to have only (a fixed amount of a commodity)|--Examples--|1947 saw the bread ration reduced|British rations were highly prized by American soldiers|refugees queued for their meagre rations|their emergency rations ran out|holidaymakers who like a generous ration of activity|petrol was so strictly rationed that bikes were always in demand|the population was rationed to four litres of water per person per day|
--Word--|rationable |--Type--|adjective, adjective|--Meanings--|Originally Scottish. Of a thing: in accordance with or conformable to reason; reasonable, just, fair.|Of a sentient being: having the faculty of reasoning; capable of reasoning; open to reason; rational, sensible.|Able to be rationed; capable of being rationed.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rationative |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|That involves ratiocination.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rational |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Based on or in accordance with reason or logic.|Able to think sensibly or logically.|Endowed with the capacity to reason.|(of a number, quantity, or expression) expressible, or containing quantities which are expressible, as a ratio of whole numbers.|--Examples--|I'm sure there's a perfectly rational explanation|Ursula's upset—she's not being very rational|man is a rational being|
--Word--|rationale |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or belief.|--Examples--|he explained the rationale behind the change|
--Word--|rationale |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or belief.|--Examples--|he explained the rationale behind the change|
--Word--|rationale |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or belief.|--Examples--|he explained the rationale behind the change|
--Word--|rationalization |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of attempting to explain or justify behaviour or an attitude with logical reasons, even if these are not appropriate.|The action of making a company, process, or industry more efficient, especially by dispensing with superfluous personnel or equipment.|The action of reorganizing a process or system so as to make it more logical and consistent.|The process of converting a function or expression to a rational form.|--Examples--|most people are prone to self-deceptive rationalization|they justify themselves with ingenious rationalizations|the London dockers struggle to preserve their jobs against ruthless rationalization|the rationalization of accounting standards|
--Word--|rationalize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Attempt to explain or justify (behaviour or an attitude) with logical reasons, even if these are not appropriate.|Make (a company, process, or industry) more efficient, especially by dispensing with superfluous personnel or equipment.|Reorganize (a process or system) so as to make it more logical and consistent.|Convert (a function or expression) to a rational form.|--Examples--|she couldn't rationalize her urge to return to the cottage|if we rationalize production, will that mean redundancies?|Parliament should seek to rationalize the country's court structure|
--Word--|rationalize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Attempt to explain or justify (behaviour or an attitude) with logical reasons, even if these are not appropriate.|Make (a company, process, or industry) more efficient, especially by dispensing with superfluous personnel or equipment.|Reorganize (a process or system) so as to make it more logical and consistent.|Convert (a function or expression) to a rational form.|--Examples--|she couldn't rationalize her urge to return to the cottage|if we rationalize production, will that mean redundancies?|Parliament should seek to rationalize the country's court structure|

--Word--|rationalize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Attempt to explain or justify (behaviour or an attitude) with logical reasons, even if these are not appropriate.|Make (a company, process, or industry) more efficient, especially by dispensing with superfluous personnel or equipment.|Reorganize (a process or system) so as to make it more logical and consistent.|Convert (a function or expression) to a rational form.|--Examples--|she couldn't rationalize her urge to return to the cottage|if we rationalize production, will that mean redundancies?|Parliament should seek to rationalize the country's court structure|
--Word--|rationalism |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The practice or principle of basing opinions and actions on reason and knowledge rather than on religious belief or emotional response.|The theory that reason rather than experience is the foundation of certainty in knowledge.|The practice of treating reason as the ultimate authority in religion.|--Examples--|scientific rationalism|
--Word--|rationalist |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A person who bases their opinions and actions on reason and knowledge rather than on religious belief or emotional response.|A person who believes that reason rather than experience is the foundation of certainty in knowledge.|A person who considers reason to be the ultimate authority in religion.|Based on reason and knowledge rather than on religious belief or emotional response.|Relating to the theory that reason rather than experience is the foundation of certainty in knowledge.|Relating to the practice of treating reason as the ultimate authority in religion.|--Examples--|the managers are rationalists who find it hard to understand why anyone should get worked up about the closure of their local hospital|a rationalist with a boyish enthusiasm for modern science|like other rationalists, he valorizes the mind over the body|the dispassionate sensibility of Protestant rationalists|a rationalist approach to the supernatural|Harvard College had become a seat of rationalist philosophy|Toland's unrelentingly rationalist approach to theology went well beyond anything Locke advocated|

--Word--|rationality |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The quality of being based on or in accordance with reason or logic.|The quality of being able to think sensibly or logically.|The quality of being endowed with the capacity to reason.|The property of a number, quantity, or expression of being expressible, or containing quantities which are expressible, as a ratio of whole numbers.|--Examples--|like any phobia, rationality plays only a small role|Scott wanted to play the character with a bit more dignity and rationality|we call rationality the distinction of man, when compared with other animals|

--Word--|rat |--Type--|noun, exclamation, verb|--Meanings--|A rodent that resembles a large mouse, typically having a pointed snout and a long tail. Some kinds have become cosmopolitan and are sometimes responsible for transmitting diseases.|A despicable person, especially a man who has been deceitful or disloyal.|An informer.|A person who is associated with or frequents a specified place.|A pad used to give shape and fullness to a woman's hair.|Used to express mild annoyance or irritation.|Hunt or kill rats.|Desert one's party, side, or cause.|Shape (hair) with a rat.|--Examples--|her rat of a husband cheated on her|he became the most famous rat in mob history|LA mall rats|ratting is second nature to a Jack Russell|many of the clans rallied to his support, others ratted and joined the King's forces|

--Word--|rat-tailed |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having a tail like that of a rat; (in early use especially of a horse) having a rat-tail.|Designating the aquatic larva of the drone fly (Eristalis tenax), which has a tail-like telescopic breathing tube that enables it to breathe air while submerged. Usually in rat-tailed maggot, rat-tailed larva.|Especially of a spoon: having a tail-like prolongation of the handle along the back of the bowl; that has a rat-tail.|Of a comb: that has a long, tapering handle at one end.|--Examples--|

--Word--|ratine |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|In early use (frequently in form ratteen): a kind of coarse twilled woollen fabric, usually with a (curled) nap; a frieze or drugget. Later: (usually in form ratine or ratiné) a plain-woven fabric made of cotton or other material with a loose open weave and rough surface, principally used for hard-wearing outer clothing, furniture covers, etc.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rattle |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Make or cause to make a rapid succession of short, sharp knocking sounds.|(of a vehicle or its occupants) move or travel with a knocking sound.|Be in or occupy (an unnecessarily spacious room or building)|Make (someone) nervous, worried, or irritated.|A rapid succession of short, sharp, sounds.|A gurgling sound in the throat of a dying person.|A thing used to make a rattling sound.|A baby's toy consisting of a container filled with small pellets, which makes a noise when shaken.|A wooden device that makes a loud noise when whirled around, formerly used by spectators at football matches.|The set of horny rings at the end of a rattlesnake's tail, shaken as a warning.|A person who talks incessantly in a lively or inane way.|--Examples--|the roof rattled with little gusts of wind|he rattled some change in his pocket|trains rattled past at frequent intervals|the house was too big—we just rattled around in it|she turned quickly, rattled by his presence|the rattle of teacups on the tray|there was a choking rattle and his eyes turned upwards|he is such a rattle!|

--Word--|Ravenna |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A city near the Adriatic coast in north-eastern central Italy; population 155,997 (2008). Ravenna became the capital of the Western Roman Empire in 402 and then of the Ostrogothic kingdom of Italy, afterwards serving as capital of Byzantine Italy. It is noted for its ancient mosaics dating from the early Christian period.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ravi |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A river in southern Asia, one of the headwaters of the River Indus, which rises in the Himalayas in Himachel Pradesh, north-western India, and flows generally south-westwards into Pakistan, where it empties into the River Chenab just north of Multan. It is one of the five rivers that gave Punjab its name.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rax |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A stretch, an act of stretching; a strain, a wrench.|Refl. To stretch oneself.|To become longer or broader, especially by being pulled; to stretch, expand.|To extend by pulling; to stretch. to rax (a person's) crag (also neck): to hang (a person).|To extend a hand or arm; to reach out. Also figurative. Frequently with adverbs, as for, over, etc.|To stretch out, extend (a part of the body); to crane (one's neck), raise (one's head).|To strain, sprain (a part of the body). Also refl. and without object with reflexive meaning: to strain or exert oneself.|To rack (one's brain, etc.).|In pass.: to be racked with pain or a disease.|--Examples--|

leg.|Seek to establish communication with someone, with the aim of offering or obtaining assistance or cooperation.|Arrive at; get as far as.|Arrive.|Attain or extend to (a specified point, level, or condition)|Succeed in achieving.|Attain or extend to (a specified point, level, or condition)|Succeed in achieving.|Succeed in influencing or having an effect on.|Make contact with (someone) by telephone or other means.|(of a broadcast or other communication) be received by.|Sail with the wind blowing from the side of the ship.|An act of reaching out with one's arm.|The distance to which someone, especially a boxer, can stretch out their hand.|The extent or range of something's application, effect, or influence.|The number of people who watch or listen to a particular broadcast or channel during a specified period.|A continuous extent of water, especially a stretch of river between two bends, or the part of a canal between locks.|A distance traversed in reaching.|--Examples--|he reached over and turned off his bedside light|she reached out to squeeze Hope's hand|Leith reached for the nearest folder|he reached out a hand and touched her hair|she reached down a plate from the cupboard|reach me those glasses|I had to stand on tiptoe and even then I could hardly reach|his style was to reach out all the time, especially to members of his own party|anyone in need of assistance should reach out to the authorities as soon as possible|Goodbye, she said as they reached the door|the show is due to reach our screens early next year|just round that corner, by them mango trees, and we reach|unemployment reached a peak in 1933|denim shorts that reach to his knees|the conference reached agreement on the draft treaty|unemployment reached a peak in 1933|denim shorts that reach to his knees|the conference reached agreement on the draft treaty|he seeks opportunities to reach viewers without journalistic interference|I've been trying to reach you all morning|television reached those parts of the electorate that other news sources could not|Brighteyes was followed round the Goldstone by Patriot, while Patriot white-sail reached|she made a reach for him|a giant, over six feet seven with a reach of over 81 inches|he told a story to illustrate the reach of his fame|the programme's daily reach is 400,000|the upper reaches of the Nile|he could sail a clear reach for Key Canaka|

--Word--|react |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Act in response to something; respond in a particular way.|Respond with hostility or a contrary course of action to.|Suffer from adverse physiological effects after ingesting, breathing, or touching a substance.|(of share prices) fall after rising.|Interact and undergo a chemical or physical change.|Cause (a substance) to undergo a chemical or physical change by interacting with another substance.|--Examples--|he reacted angrily to the news of his dismissal|the market reacted by falling a further 3.1%|they reacted against the elite art music of their time|many babies react to soy-based formulas|the shares reacted to 222p before rallying to 228p|the sulphur in the coal reacts with the limestone during combustion|in the new process the ammonia will be reacted with oxygen|

--Word--|reactance |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The non-resistive component of impedance in an AC circuit, arising from the effect of inductance or capacitance or both and causing the current to be out of phase with the electromotive force causing it.|--Examples--|the capacitor exhibits negligible reactance at the operating frequency|complicated combinations of reactances and resistances|

--Word--|reaction |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Something done, felt, or thought in response to a situation or event.|A person's ability to respond physically and mentally to external stimuli.|An adverse physiological response to a substance that has been breathed in, ingested, or touched.|A mode of thinking or behaving that is deliberately different from previous modes of thought and behaviour.|Opposition to political or social progress or reform.|A chemical process in which substances act mutually on each other and are changed into different substances, or one substance changes into other substances.|An analogous transformation of atomic nuclei or other particles.|A force exerted in opposition to an applied force.|--Examples--|my immediate reaction was one of relief|prices fell in reaction to intense competition|a skilled driver with quick reactions|such allergic reactions as hay fever and asthma|the work of these painters was a reaction against Fauvism|the institution is under threat from the forces of reaction|a chemical reaction caused by a build-up of particular sodium salts|reactions between photons and electrically charged atomic particles|the law of action and reaction|

read|I never learned to read music|Emily read over her notes|I'll go to bed and read for a while|only three of the girls could read and none could write|I read the letter to her|the charges against looked down, terrified that he would read fear on her face|he didn't dare look away, in case this was read as a sign of weakness|the brief note read like a cry for help|I've come to read the gas meter|the thermometer read 0° C|I'm reading English at Cambridge|he went to Manchester to read for a BA in Economics|it attempts to read a floppy disk without regard to its format|the commonest way of reading a file into the system|the microchip gives a unique code when read by the scanner|the bill was accordingly read a second time|Do you read me? Over.|I was having a quiet read of the newspaper|the book is a thoroughly entertaining read|their read on the national situation may be correct|

--Word--|readjuster |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who readjusts something.|US. Also with capital initial. A citizen of Virginia who advocated a reduction of the debt incurred by that state before the Civil War; specifically a member of a political faction that supported this position, formed in 1877–8 and active through the 1880s. Compare funder. Now historical.|--Examples--|

--Word--|read |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Look at and comprehend the meaning of (written or printed matter) by interpreting the characters or symbols of which it is composed.|Have the ability to look at and comprehend the meaning of written or printed matter.|Speak (the written or printed matter that one is reading) aloud.|Habitually read (a particular newspaper or periodical)|(of a passage, text, or sign) have a certain wording.|Used to indicate that a particular word in a text or passage is incorrect and that another should be substituted for it.|(of an actor) audition for (a role)|Discover (information) by reading it in a written or printed source.|Having a specified level of knowledge as a result of reading.|Discern (a fact, emotion, or quality) in someone's eyes or expression.|Understand or interpret the nature or significance of.|(of a piece of writing) convey a specified impression to the reader.|Inspect and record the figure indicated on (a measuring instrument)|(of a measuring instrument) indicate a specified measurement or figure.|Study (an academic subject) at a university.|(of a computer) copy, transfer, or interpret (data)|Enter or extract (data) in an electronic storage device.|(of a device) obtain data from (light or other input)|Present (a bill or other measure) before a legislative assembly.|Hear and understand the words of (someone speaking on a radio transmitter)|A period or act of reading something.|A book considered in terms of its readability.|A person's interpretation of something.|--Examples--|it's the best novel I've ever read|I never learned to read music|Emily read over her notes|I'll go to bed and read for a while|only three of the girls could read and none could write|I read the letter to her|the charges against him were read out|I'll read to you if you like|now, I know what my reputation is—I read the papers|the placard read We want justice|for madam read madman|ring your agent and say you'll read for the part|he was arrested yesterday—I read it in the paper|I read about the course in a magazine|Ada was well read in French literature|he is a man deeply read in history, philosophy, and theology|she looked down, terrified that he would read fear on her face|he didn't dare look away, in case this was read as a sign of weakness|the brief note read like a cry for help|I've come to read the gas meter|the thermometer read 0° C|I'm reading English at Cambridge|he went to Manchester to read for a BA in Economics|it attempts to read a floppy disk without regard to its format|the commonest way of reading a file into the system|the microchip gives a unique code when read by the scanner|the bill was accordingly read a second time|Do you read me? Over.|I was having a quiet read of the newspaper|the book is a thoroughly entertaining read|their read on the national situation may be correct|

--Word--|Reagan, Ronald |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1911–2004), American Republican statesman, 40th president of the US 1981–9; full name Ronald Wilson Reagan. He was a Hollywood actor before entering politics. His presidency saw the launch of the Strategic Defense Initiative and cuts in taxes and social services budgets, as well as the Irangate scandal and the signing of an intermediate nuclear forces non-proliferation treaty, both in 1987.|--Examples--|

--Word--|realism |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The attitude or practice of accepting a situation as it is and being prepared to deal with it accordingly.|The view that the subject matter of politics is political power, not matters of principle.|The doctrine that the law is better understood by analysis of judges rather than the judgements given.|The quality or fact of representing a person or thing in a way that is accurate and true to life.|An artistic or literary movement or style characterized by the representation of people or things as they actually are.|The doctrine that universals or abstract concepts have an objective or absolute existence. The theory that universals have their own reality is sometimes called Platonic realism because it was first outlined by Plato's doctrine of forms or ideas.|The doctrine that matter as the object of perception has real existence and is neither reducible to universal mind or spirit nor dependent on a perceiving agent.|--Examples--|the summit was marked by a new mood of realism|political realism is the oldest approach to global politics|modern jurists have tended to underestimate the scope of American legal realism|British soaps will stay because of their gritty realism|
--Word--|realism |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The attitude or practice of accepting a situation as it is and being prepared to deal with it accordingly.|The view that the subject matter of politics is political power, not matters of principle.|The doctrine that the law is better understood by analysis of judges rather than the judgements given.|The quality or fact of representing a person or thing in a way that is accurate and true to life.|An artistic or literary movement or style characterized by the representation of people or things as they actually are.|The doctrine that universals or abstract concepts have an objective or absolute existence. The theory that universals have their own reality is sometimes called Platonic realism because it was first outlined by Plato's doctrine of forms or ideas.|The doctrine that matter as the object of perception has real existence and is neither reducible to universal mind or spirit nor dependent on a perceiving agent.|--Examples--|the summit was marked by a new mood of realism|political realism is the oldest approach to global politics|modern jurists have tended to underestimate the scope of American legal realism|British soaps will stay because of their gritty realism|
--Word--|realist |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A person who accepts a situation as it is and is prepared to deal with it accordingly.|A person who believes that the subject matter of politics is political power, not matters of principle.|An artist or writer whose style is characterized by the representation of people or things as they actually are.|A person who believes in the theory of realism.|Accepting a situation as it is and being prepared to deal with it accordingly.|Relating to or denoting the view that the subject matter of politics is political power, not matters of principle.|Representing a person or thing in a way that is accurate and true to life.|Relating to an artistic or literary movement or style characterized by the representation of people or things as they actually are.|Relating to or denoting the theory of realism.|--Examples--|I am a realist, with no time for your world of make believe|the classical realist believes that the state is the most important actor in the international system|Dickens and other nineteenth-century realists|modern philosophical realists|a realist view of the world, its problems, and its future|a political realist standpoint|a realist drama|realist painters and sculptors|a realist theory of perception|
--Word--|realistic |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having or showing a sensible and practical idea of what can be achieved or expected.|Representing things in a way that is accurate and true to life.|--Examples--|I thought we had a realistic chance of winning|a realistic human drama|
--Word--|realistically |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|In a way that demonstrates a sensible and practical idea of what can be achieved or expected.|In a way that is accurate and true to life.|--Examples--|how well can each candidate realistically expect to do?|realistically, at his age opportunities are few and far between|this film realistically simulates the effects that a nuclear war could have|Cubist artists did not try to paint realistically|

--Word--|realization |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An act of becoming fully aware of something as a fact.|The achievement of something desired or anticipated.|An actual form given to a concept or work.|The way in which a particular linguistic feature is used in speech or writing on a particular occasion.|An instance or embodiment of an abstract group as the set of symmetry operations of some object or set.|A particular series which might be generated by a specified random process.|The conversion of an asset into cash.|A sale of goods.|--Examples--|a growing realization of the need to create common economic structures|realization dawned suddenly|he did not live to see the realization of his dream|a perfect realization of Bartók's Second Violin Concerto on disc|verbal sequences were produced using segmental realization|vowels have a startlingly wide range of realizations|the realization of his assets in Spain|auction realizations|

--Word--|realize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Become fully aware of (something) as a fact; understand clearly.|Cause to happen.|Achieve (something desired or anticipated); fulfil.|Give actual or physical form to.|Use (a linguistic feature) in a particular spoken or written form.|Add to or complete (a piece of music left sparsely notated by the composer)|Make (a profit) from a transaction.|Be sold for.|Convert (an asset) into cash.|--Examples--|he realized his mistake at once|they realized that something was wrong|his worst fears have been realized|it is only now that she is beginning to realize her potential|the stage designs have been beautifully realized|the item can be realized with a fully low front vowel|other reconstruction work has involved realizing short score into full score|she realized a profit of $100,000|the drawings are expected to realize £500,000|he realized all the assets in her trust fund|

--Word--|really |--Type--|adverb, exclamation|--Meanings--|In actual fact, as opposed to what is said or imagined to be true or possible.|Used to emphasize a statement or opinion.|Seriously (used in questions and exclamations with an implied negative answer)|Very; thoroughly.|Used to express interest, surprise, or doubt.|Used to express mild protest.|Used to express agreement.|--Examples--|so what really happened?|they're not really my aunt and uncle|really, there are only three options|I really want to go|I'm sorry, Ruth, I really am|do you really expect me to believe that?|I think she's really great|a really cold day|I've been working hard. Really?|really, Marjorie, you do jump to conclusions!|It's a nightmare finding somewhere to live in this town. Yeah, really.|

--Word--|real |--Type--|adjective, adverb|--Meanings--|Actually existing as a thing or occurring in fact; not imagined or supposed.|Used to emphasize the significance or seriousness of a situation.|Relating to something as it is, not merely as it may be described or distinguished.|(of a thing) not imitation or artificial; genuine.|True or actual.|Rightly so called; proper.|Complete; utter (used for emphasis)|Adjusted for changes in the value of money; assessed by purchasing power.|(of a number or quantity) having no imaginary part.|(of an image) of a kind in which the light that forms it actually passes through it; not virtual.|Really; very.|--Examples--|Julius Caesar was a real person|her many illnesses, real and imaginary|there is a real danger of civil war|the competitive threat from overseas is very real|Locke's distinction between the real and nominal essence of substances|the earring was presumably real gold|his real name is James|this isn't my real reason for coming|he's my idea of a real man|the tour turned out to be a real disaster|real incomes had fallen by 30 per cent|an increase in real terms of 11.6 per cent|my head hurts real bad|

--Word--|reason |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A cause, explanation, or justification for an action or event.|Good or obvious cause to do something.|A premise of an argument in support of a belief, especially a minor premise when given after the conclusion.|The power of the mind to think, understand, and form judgements logically.|What is right, practical, or possible; common sense.|One's sanity.|Think, understand, and form judgements logically.|Find an answer to a problem by considering possible options.|Persuade (someone) with rational argument.|--Examples--|she asked him to return, but didn't give a reason|I resigned for personal reasons|Giles is the reason that I am here|we have reason to celebrate|there is a close connection between reason and emotion|people are willing, within reason, to pay for schooling|she is in danger of losing her reason|humans do not reason entirely from facts|she was growing too sleepy to reason it out|I tried to reason with her, but without success|

--Word--|reasonable |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having sound judgement; fair and sensible.|Based on good sense.|Able to reason logically.|As much as is appropriate or fair; moderate.|Fairly good; average.|(of a price or product) not too expensive.|--Examples--|no reasonable person could have objected|it seems a reasonable enough request|the guilt of a person on trial must be proved beyond reasonable doubt|man is by nature reasonable|a police officer may use reasonable force to gain entry|the carpet is in reasonable condition|a restaurant serving excellent food at reasonable prices|they are lovely shoes and very reasonable|
--Word--|reasonableness |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Sound judgement; fairness.|The quality of being based on good sense.|The quality of being as much as is appropriate or fair; moderateness.|--Examples--|days which demand wise restraint and calm reasonableness|he critically evaluated the reasonableness of each assumption|disputes about the reasonableness of certain costs|
--Word--|reasonably |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|In a sensible way.|By sensible standards of judgement; justifiably.|To a moderate or acceptable degree; fairly.|Inexpensively.|--Examples--|he began to talk calmly and reasonably about his future|a constable who reasonably believes a breach of the peace is about to take place|it was assumed, reasonably enough, that the murder had taken place by the pond|she played the piano reasonably well|ski wear which looks good and is reasonably priced|

--Word--|Rebecca |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The (notional) leader of a movement whose supporters attacked and demolished turnpike toll gates chiefly in south and west Wales in the period between 1839–44 in protest at high tolls; (also) a member of such a group of protesters. In later use applied to similar groups carrying out other acts of social protest, especially organized salmon-poaching raids.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Rebekah |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Originally: a holder of the degree of Rebekah, an honorary rank established in 1851 to be conferred upon the wives or daughters of members of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows. Later: a member of the Rebekahs, the female counterpart to the Odd Fellows which developed from this. Occasionally attributive, as Rebekah lodge.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rebound |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Bounce back through the air after hitting something hard.|Gain possession of a missed shot after it bounces off the backboard or basket rim.|Recover in value, amount, or strength after a decrease or decline.|(of an event or action) have an unexpected adverse consequence for (someone, especially the person responsible for it)|(in sporting contexts) a ball or shot that bounces back after striking a hard surface.|A recovery of possession of a missed shot.|An increase in value, amount, or strength after a previous decline.|The recurrence of a medical condition, especially after withdrawal of medication.|--Examples--|his shot hammered into the post and rebounded across the goal|he proved that he can score and rebound as well as any of his peers|the Share Index rebounded to show a twenty-point gain|Nicholas's tricks are rebounding on him|he blasted the rebound into the net|he had twenty-two points and six rebounds, and missed only three shots|they revealed a big rebound in profits for last year|rebound hypertension|

--Word--|recall |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Bring (a fact, event, or situation) back into one's mind; remember.|Cause one to remember or think of.|Bring the memory or thought of someone or something to (a person or their mind)|Call up (stored computer data) for processing or display.|Officially order (someone) to return to a place.|Select (a sports player) as a member of a team from which they have previously been dropped.|(of a manufacturer) request all the purchasers of (a certain product) to return it, as the result of the discovery of a fault.|Bring (someone) out of a state of inattention or reverie.|Revoke or annul (an action or decision)|The action or faculty of remembering something learned or experienced.|An act or instance of officially recalling someone or something.|The removal of an elected government official from office by a petition followed by voting.|The proportion of the number of relevant documents retrieved from a database in response to an enquiry.|--Examples--|I can still vaguely recall being taken to the hospital|he recalled how he felt at the time|the film's analysis of contemporary concerns recalls The Big Chill|the smell of a blackcurrant bush has ever since recalled to me that evening|students can recall templates or stored formats|the Panamanian ambassador was recalled from Peru|the Fulham defender has been recalled to the Welsh squad for the World Cup|all 5,128 of its UK Corsas were being recalled because of an electrical fault|her action recalled him to the present|he sent another note to Lord Grey recalling his earlier communication|people's understanding and subsequent recall of stories or events|a recall of Parliament|expert systems can produce solutions with the speed, recall, accuracy, and consistency that only a computer can provide|

--Word--|recarbonate |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|To restore the amount of carbon dioxide or carbonate in (a substance) to previous levels; to reintroduce carbon dioxide into (a liquid); to convert back into a carbonate; (occasionally) to recarbonize. Also without object: to take up carbon dioxide or carbonate again.|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarbonation |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action or process of recarbonating a substance.|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarbonization |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action or process of recarbonizing a substance; an instance of this.|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarbonize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|To recombine (a substance) with carbon; to reintroduce carbon into or increase the carbon content of (a metal, alloy, etc.).|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarbonize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|To recombine (a substance) with carbon; to reintroduce carbon into or increase the carbon content of (a metal, alloy, etc.).|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarburization |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Originally: the addition of carbon (typically in the form of coke, anthracite, or a carbon-rich alloy) to steel following decarburization, in order to produce the desired degree of hardness and strength. Later also more widely: = recarbonization.|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarburize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|To subject (steel) to recarburization.|--Examples--|
--Word--|recarburizing |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|= recarburization.|That brings about recarburization.|--Examples--|
