--Word--|repair |--Type--|verb, noun, verb, noun|--Meanings--|Restore (something damaged, faulty, or worn) to a good condition.|Make good (damage)|Put right (an unwelcome situation)|The action of repairing something.|A result of repairing something.|The relative physical condition of an object.|Go to (a place), especially in company.|Frequent or habitual visiting of a place.|A place which is frequently visited or occupied.|--Examples--|faulty electrical appliances should be repaired by an electrician|an operation to repair damage to his neck|the new government moved quickly to repair relations with the USA|the truck was beyond repair|the abandoned house they bought needs repairs|a coat of French polish was brushed over the repair|the hospital is in a bad state of repair|we repaired to the tranquillity of a nearby cafe|she exhorted repair to the church|the repairs of wild beasts|

--Word--|reparation |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of making amends for a wrong one has done, by providing payment or other assistance to those who have been wronged.|The compensation for war damage paid by a defeated state.|The action of repairing something.|--Examples--|the courts required a convicted offender to make financial reparation to his victim|the Treaty of Versailles imposed heavy reparations and restrictions on Germany|the old hall was pulled down to avoid the cost of reparation|

--Word--|repeat |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Say again something one has already said.|Say again (something said or written by someone else)|Say or do the same thing again.|Used for emphasis.|Do (something) again or more than once.|Broadcast (a television or radio programme) again.|Undertake (a course or period of instruction) again.|Occur again in the same way or form.|Illegally vote more than once in an election.|Attain an achievement again, especially by winning a championship for the second consecutive time.|(of a watch or clock) strike (the last hour or quarter) over again when required.|(of food) be tasted intermittently for some time after being swallowed as a result of belching or indigestion.|Something that occurs or is done again.|A repeated broadcast of a television or radio programme.|Occurring, done, or used more than once.|A consignment of goods similar to one already received.|A decorative pattern which is repeated uniformly over a surface.|A passage intended to be repeated.|A mark indicating a passage to be repeated.|--Examples--|Are you hurt? he repeated|Billy repeated his question|Ann repeated that she was very comfortable|he repeated the words after me|she repeated what I'd said|she was fretful and kept repeating herself|force was not—repeat, not—to be used|earlier experiments were repeated on a larger scale|the thirteen episodes from the first two series were constantly repeated|Mark had to repeat first and second grades|I don't intend to let history repeat itself|the first team in nineteen years to repeat as NBA champions|a watch repeater that repeats hours and quarters|that cucumber repeated on me for hours|the final will be a repeat of last year|she goes home alone to TV dinners and repeats of I Love Lucy|a repeat prescription|a repeat offender|rugs with simple repeat patterns|

--Word--|repeatable |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Able to be done again.|Suitable to be said again.|--Examples--|repeatable experiments under laboratory conditions|an easily repeatable routine|some of the words he's known to use are not repeatable on TV|
--Word--|repeatable |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Able to be done again.|Suitable to be said again.|--Examples--|repeatable experiments under laboratory conditions|an easily repeatable routine|some of the words he's known to use are not repeatable on TV|
--Word--|repeated |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Done or occurring again several times in the same way.|--Examples--|there were repeated attempts to negotiate|despite repeated requests, neither company gave a satisfactory answer|
--Word--|repeatedly |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|Over and over again; constantly.|--Examples--|they have been warned repeatedly with no effect|
--Word--|repeater |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person or thing that repeats something.|A firearm which fires several shots without reloading.|A watch or clock which repeats its last strike when required.|A device for the automatic retransmission or amplification of an electrically transmitted message.|A railway signal indicating the state of another that is out of sight.|--Examples--|a fast-fire repeater|

--Word--|repêchage |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(in rowing and other sports) a contest in which the best-placed of those who failed to win heats compete for a place in the final.|--Examples--|
--Word--|repel |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Drive or force (an attack or attacker) back or away.|(of a magnetic pole or electric field) force (something similarly magnetized or charged) away from itself.|(of a substance) resist mixing with or be impervious to (another substance)|Be repulsive or distasteful to.|Refuse to accept (something, especially an argument or theory)|--Examples--|government units sought to repel the rebels|electrically charged objects attract or repel one another|like poles repel and unlike poles attract|boots with good-quality leather uppers to repel moisture|she was repelled by the permanent smell of drink on his breath|the alleged right of lien led by the bankrupt's solicitor was repelled|
--Word--|repellence |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|--Examples--|
--Word--|repellent |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Able to repel a particular thing; impervious to a particular substance.|Causing disgust or distaste.|A substance that deters insects or other pests from approaching or settling.|A substance used to treat something, especially fabric or stone, so as to make it impervious to water.|--Examples--|water-repellent nylon|the idea was slightly repellent to her|a flea repellent|treat brick with a silicone water repellent|

--Word--|repetition |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of repeating something that has already been said or written.|A piece set by a teacher to be learned by heart and recited.|The recurrence of an action or event.|A thing repeated.|A training exercise which is repeated, especially a series of repeated raisings and lowerings of the weight in weight training.|The repeating of a passage or note.|--Examples--|her comments are worthy of repetition|a repetition of his reply to the delegation|there was to be no repetition of the interwar years|I didn't want a repetition of the scene in my office that morning|the geometric repetitions of Islamic art|lie on your back and bench-press a light weight very quickly over ten repetitions|the tune is full of melodic repetition and sequence|

--Word--|replay |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Play back (a recording on tape, video, or film)|Repeat (something, especially an event)|Play (a match) again to decide a winner after the original encounter ended in a draw or contentious result.|The playing again of part of a recording, especially so as to be able to watch an incident more closely.|An occurrence which closely follows the pattern of a previous event.|A replayed match.|--Examples--|he could stop the tape and replay it whenever he wished|she replayed in her mind every detail of the night before|United were ordered to replay their FA Cup match|clouds can be studied in speeded-up replay|the umpire studied TV replays|the second goal was a replay of the first|Wilson equalized to earn a replay|

--Word--|replicate |--Type--|verb, adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Make an exact copy of; reproduce.|(of genetic material or a living organism) reproduce or give rise to a copy of itself.|Repeat (a scientific experiment or trial) to obtain a consistent result.|Of the nature of a copy.|Of the nature of a repetition of a scientific experiment or trial.|A close or exact copy; a replica.|A repeated experiment or trial.|A tone one or more octaves above or below the given tone.|--Examples--|it might be impractical to replicate Eastern culture in the west|interleukin-16 prevents the virus from replicating itself|in order to replicate, cells must make copies of their DNA|these findings have been replicated by Metzger and Antes|a replicate Earth|the variation of replicate measurements|young reptiles should not be considered merely small replicates of adults|five replicates were performed per dilution|

--Word--|replication |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of copying or reproducing something.|A copy.|The repetition of a scientific experiment or trial to obtain a consistent result.|The process by which genetic material or a living organism gives rise to a copy of itself.|A plaintiff's reply to the defendant's plea.|--Examples--|the extraordinary speed and replication of information created by computerization|a twentieth-century building would be cheaper than a replication of what was there before|on its own, replication does not validate a theory derived from experimental results|DNA replication|a crucial step in cold virus replications|in the replication the plaintiff went on to state many additional facts|

--Word--|repone |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|To restore (a person) to a position or office previously held, to reinstate; especially to restore (a deposed minister) to the ministry. Formerly also with †in, †to. Now historical.|Law. To restore to a former legal status; especially to restore (a person) to his or her right to defend a case, typically after a decree in absence has been granted. Frequently against a previous judgment. Formerly also with †to. Formerly also †without object. Usually in pass.|Scottish. To give as a reply; to answer. Also without object: to reply. rare after 17th cent.|--Examples--|

--Word--|report |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Give a spoken or written account of something that one has observed, heard, done, or investigated.|Cover an event or subject as a journalist or a reporter.|Used to indicate that something has been stated, although one cannot confirm its accuracy.|Make a formal statement or complaint about (someone or something) to the necessary authority.|(of a parliamentary committee chairman) formally announce that the committee has dealt with (a bill)|(of a committee of Congress) return a bill to the legislative body for action.|Present oneself formally as having arrived at a particular place or as ready to do something.|Return to work or duty after a period of absence.|Be responsible to (a superior or supervisor)|An account given of a particular matter, especially in the form of an official document, after thorough investigation or consideration by an appointed person or body.|A spoken or written description of an event or situation, especially one intended for publication or broadcasting in the media.|A teacher's written assessment of a pupil's work, progress, and conduct, issued at the end of a term or school year.|A detailed formal account of a case heard in a court, giving the main points in the judgement, especially as prepared for publication.|A piece of information that is unsupported by firm evidence.|Rumour.|A sudden loud noise of or like an explosion or gunfire.|An employee who reports to another employee.|The reputation of someone or something.|--Examples--|the minister reported a decline in milk production|police reported that the floods were abating|the teacher should report on the child's progress|the public disliked the way that the media reported on the scandal|the Egyptian news agency reported that a coup attempt had taken place|hoaxers are reported to be hacking into airline frequencies to impersonate air traffic controllers|undisclosed illegalities are reported to the company's directors|eight Yorkshire terriers have been reported missing in the last month|the Chairman shall report the Bill to the House|the Committee reported out the Civil Rights Bill, quicker than ever expected|he had to report to the headmaster at 4 pm|hearing that there was the prospect of action with No. 8 Commando, he reported back for duty|he reports to the chairman of the committee|the chairman's annual report|press reports suggested that the secret police were helping to maintain public order|reports were circulating that the chairman was about to resign|report has it that the beetles have now virtually disappeared|all our horses are very gentle and are accustomed to hearing the report of a .22|whatsoever things are lovely and of good report|

--Word--|reportage |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The reporting of news by the press and the broadcasting media.|The factual, journalistic presentation of an account in a book or other text.|--Examples--|extensive reportage of elections|the area where fiction borders with reportage|

--Word--|reported |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having been formally or officially announced or described.|Described or talked of, but not verified or confirmed.|--Examples--|an increase in reported crime|there have been 122 reported cases of influenza in Boston since October|he's now a reported £50,000 in debt|fans were agog with news of a reported training ground bust-up|
--Word--|reportedly |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|According to what some say (used to express the speaker's belief that the information given is not necessarily true)|--Examples--|he was in El Salvador, reportedly on his way to Texas|

--Word--|repose |--Type--|noun, verb, verb|--Meanings--|A state of rest, sleep, or tranquillity.|The state of being calm and composed.|Harmonious arrangement of colours and forms, providing a restful visual effect.|Be situated or kept in a particular place.|Lie down in rest.|Lay something to rest in or on.|Give rest to.|Place something, especially one's confidence or trust, in.|--Examples--|in repose her face looked relaxed|he had lost none of his grace or his repose|many of the qualities of the great Piero della Francescas—the sense of grand stasis, of timeless repose—seem strongly reincarnated in this work|the diamond now reposes in the Louvre|how sweetly he would repose in the four-poster bed|I'll go to him, and repose our distresses on his friendly bosom|he halted to repose his way-worn soldiers|we have never betrayed the trust that you have reposed in us|

--Word--|representation |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of speaking or acting on behalf of someone or the state of being so represented.|The description or portrayal of someone or something in a particular way.|The depiction of someone or something in a work of art.|A picture, model, or other depiction of someone or something.|(in some theories of perception) a mental state or concept regarded as corresponding to a thing perceived.|Formal statements made to an authority, especially so as to communicate an opinion or register a protest.|A statement or allegation.|--Examples--|you may qualify for free legal representation|the representation of women in newspapers|Picasso is striving for some absolute representation of reality|a striking representation of a vase of flowers|the Law Society will make representations to the Lord Chancellor|any buyer was relying on a representation that the tapes were genuine|

--Word--|representative |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Typical of a class, group, or body of opinion.|Containing typical examples of many or all types.|(of a legislative assembly or deliberative body) consisting of people chosen to act and speak on behalf of a wider group.|(of a government or political system) based on elected or chosen representatives.|Serving as a portrayal or symbol of something.|(of art) representational.|Relating to mental representation.|A person chosen or appointed to act or speak for another or others.|A person chosen or elected to speak and act on behalf of others in a legislative assembly or deliberative body.|A delegate who attends a conference, negotiations, etc., so as to represent the interests of another person or group.|An agent of a firm who travels to potential clients to sell its products.|An employee of a travel company who lives in a resort and looks after the needs of its holidaymakers.|An example of a class or group.|--Examples--|Churchill was not properly representative of influential opinion in Britain|a representative sample of young people in Scotland|the new government lacked a representative assembly|there was no representative body to fight for cricketers until 1968|free elections and representative democracy|the show would be more representative of how women really are|the bust involves a high degree of representative abstraction|the Duke of Gloucester would attend the coronation as the representative of his father, King George V|the District of Columbia's representative in Congress|the Cambodian representative to the UN|a PLO representative attending a meeting in Damascus|a sales representative for Norwich Union|make your own way to the Valley Inn, where you will be contacted by our tour representative|fossil representatives of lampreys and hagfishes|

--Word--|representer |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Something which stands for, signifies, or denotes another; an image, a sign, a symbol.|A representative of a person, group, country, etc.; a spokesperson, a deputy.|Specifically = representative. archaic and rare in later use.|Generally. A person who or thing which depicts, portrays, or renders something perceptible to the senses.|A person who puts forward a statement or account, especially with a view to influencing action or to creating a particular impression of a matter; (in later use) (Law) (a) a person who makes a statement which forms the basis of a contract; (b) a complainant, a petitioner (now rare).|Church History. In plural The authors of the Representation presented to the General Assembly of the Kirk of Scotland in 1721 in connection with the Marrow Controversy.|--Examples--|

--Word--|repression |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of subduing someone or something by force.|The restraint, prevention, or inhibition of a feeling, quality, etc.|The action or process of suppressing a thought or desire in oneself so that it remains unconscious.|--Examples--|students sparked off events that ended in brutal repression|the tsarist repressions|the repression of anger can be positively harmful|children and adults pay a heavy price for their deep repression of thoughts about death|an extraordinary panoply of sexual repressions and desires|

--Word--|reptile |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A vertebrate animal of a class that includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, and tortoises. They are distinguished by having a dry scaly skin and typically laying soft-shelled eggs on land.|A person regarded with loathing and contempt.|Belonging to a reptile or to the class of reptiles.|--Examples--|are you contradicting me, you ignorant little reptile?|reptile eggs|
--Word--|reptile |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A vertebrate animal of a class that includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, and tortoises. --Word--|reptility |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|(A) The nature or condition of being reptilian. (b) figurative. Reptilian character or conduct; devious or sly behaviour; baseness.|--Examples--|
--Word--|Reptilia |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Treated as plural. Originally: those animals which creep or crawl. In later use (Zoology): the class of vertebrates which comprises the reptiles (snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, tortoises, and many extinct forms).|--Examples--|

--Word--|requisitory |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|In French law: a formal charge made against an accused person by a public prosecutor, in which a demand is made for a specific punishment. Frequently as postpositive, especially in letter requisitory.|Capable of making a requisition. Now rare.|--Examples--|

--Word--|receive |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Be given, presented with, or paid (something)|Take delivery of (something sent or communicated)|Consent to hear (an oath or confession)|Buy or accept goods known to be stolen.|Suffer, experience, or be subject to (specified treatment)|Respond to (something) in a specified way.|Meet and have to withstand.|Meet with (a specified reaction)|Widely accepted as authoritative or true.|Greet or welcome (a visitor) formally.|Be visited by.|Admit as a member.|Form (an idea or impression) as a result of perception or experience.|Detect or pick up (broadcast signals)|Serve as a receptacle for.|Provide space or accommodation for.|(in tennis and similar games) be the player to whom the server serves (the ball).|Eat or drink (the Eucharistic bread or wine)|--Examples--|the band will receive a £100,000 advance|she received her prize from the manager|he received fifty enquiries after advertising the job|he failed to find a magistrate to receive his oath|he was deprived of his licence for receiving a stolen load of whisky|the event received wide press coverage|she received only cuts and bruises|her first poem was not well received|the landward slopes receive the full force of the wind|the rulings have received widespread acceptance|the myths and received wisdom about the country's past|representatives of the club will be received by the Mayor|she was not allowed to receive visitors|hundreds of converts were received into the Church|the impression she received was one of unhurried leisure|the systems work by comparing time signals received from different satellites|the basin that receives your blood|the remaining lines receive the general rolling stock|he received Communion and left|

--Word--|recognize |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Identify (someone or something) from having encountered them before; know again.|Identify from knowledge of appearance or character.|(of a computer or other machine) automatically identify and respond correctly to (a sound, printed character, etc.)|Acknowledge the existence, validity, or legality of.|Show official appreciation of; reward formally.|Officially regard (a qualification) as valid or proper.|Grant diplomatic recognition to (a country or government)|(of a person presiding at a meeting or debate) call on (someone) to speak.|--Examples--|I recognized her when her wig fell off|Julia hardly recognized Jill when they met|Pat is very good at recognizing wild flowers|Dr Friedman is programming his computer to recognize the shapes of strokes in the hands of various writers|the defence is recognized in British law|he was recognized as an international authority|his work was recognized by an honorary degree from Glasgow University|these qualifications are recognized by the Department of Education|countries which recognized East Germany|they were refusing to recognize the puppet regime|

--Word--|reserve |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Retain for future use.|Use or engage in something only in or at (a particular circumstance or time)|(in church use) retain (a portion of the consecrated elements) after Mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.|Retain or hold (a right or entitlement), especially by formal or legal stipulation.|Arrange for (a room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person.|Refrain from delivering (a judgement or decision) without due consideration or evidence.|A supply of a commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required.|Funds kept available by a bank, company, or government.|A part of a company's profits added to capital rather than paid as a dividend.|A body of troops withheld from action to reinforce or protect others, or additional to the regular forces and available in an emergency.|A member of the military reserve.|An extra player who is a possible substitute in a team.|The second-choice team.|A place set aside for special use.|A reservation for an indigenous people.|A protected area for wildlife.|A lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression.|A feeling of doubt qualifying acceptance of a person, statement, or plan.|(in the decoration of ceramics or textiles) an area in which the original material or background colour remains visible.|--Examples--|roll out half the dough and reserve the other half|Japanese food has been presented as expensive and reserved for special occasions|the editor reserves the right to edit letters|a place was reserved for her in the front row|I'll reserve my views on his ability until he's played again|Australia has major coal, gas, and uranium reserves|foreign exchange reserves|the bank built up a cash reserve of £2bn to meet any run on the bank once the loss was revealed|the men were stationed as a central reserve ready to be transported wherever necessary|the army began calling up reserves for combat training|he was --Word--|resolution |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A firm decision to do or not to do something.|A formal expression of opinion or intention agreed on by a legislative body or other formal meeting, typically after taking a vote.|The quality of being determined or resolute.|The action of solving a problem or contentious matter.|The passing of a discord into a concord during the course of changing harmony.|The disappearance of a symptom or condition.|The process of reducing or separating something into constituent parts or components.|The replacing of a single force or other vector quantity by two or more jointly equivalent to it.|The smallest interval measurable by a telescope or other scientific instrument; the resolving power.|The degree of detail visible in a photographic or television image.|The conversion of something abstract into another form.|The substitution of two short syllables for one long one.|--Examples--|she kept her resolution not to see Anne any more|a New Year's resolution|the conference passed two resolutions|he handled the last British actions of the war with resolution|the peaceful resolution of all disputes|a successful resolution to the problem|tension is released by the resolution from the dominant to the tonic chord|complete remission was defined as resolution of clinical evidence of disease|a high-resolution monitor|the gradual resolution of an uncertain feeling into a named emotion|

--Word--|respond |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Say something in reply.|(of a congregation) say or sing the response in reply to a priest.|(of a person) do something as a reaction to someone or something.|React quickly or positively to a stimulus or treatment.|Make (a bid) in answer to one's partner's preceding bid.|A half-pillar or half-pier attached to a wall to support an arch, especially at the end of an arcade.|(in church use) a response to a versicle; a responsory.|--Examples--|she could not get Robert to respond to her words|he responded that it would not be feasible|It's not part of my job, Belinda responded|she responded to his grin with a smile|his back injury has failed to respond to treatment|to partner's opening one heart it is dangerous to respond two clubs|East would have responded holding a high spade honour plus an ace|
--Word--|response |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A verbal or written answer.|An answer to a question in a test, questionnaire, etc.|A part of a religious liturgy said or sung by a congregation in answer to a minister or cantor.|A reaction to something.|An excitation of a nerve impulse caused by a change or event; a physical reaction to a specific stimulus or situation.|The way in which a mechanical or electrical device responds to a stimulus or stimuli.|A bid made in answer to one's partner's preceding bid.|--Examples--|there was laughter at his response to the question|we received 400 applications in response to one job ad|table 3.1 shows the mean number of correct responses given by each age group|an extended, jazzy piano solo drew the biggest response from the crowd|an Honours degree course in Japanese has been established in response to an increasing demand|we unwittingly induce Pavlovian-type responses in dogs by establishing a rigid routine for feeding|there is considerable species variation in the stomach's response to alcohol|the throttle response from the 1870 cc engine is almost petrol sharp|

--Word--|restoration |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of returning something to a former owner, place, or condition.|The process of restoring a building, work of art, etc. to its original condition.|The reinstatement of a previous practice, right, or situation.|A structure provided to replace or repair dental tissue so as to restore its form and function, such as a filling, crown, or bridge.|A model or drawing representing the supposed original form of an extinct animal, ruined building, etc.|The return of a monarch to a throne, a head of state to government, or a regime to power.|The re-establishment of Charles II as King of England in 1660. After the death of Oliver Cromwell in 1658, his son Richard (1626–1712) proved incapable of maintaining the Protectorate, and General Monck organized the king's return from exile.|The period following the Restoration of Charles II.|The restoration of the Bourbon monarchy in France in 1814, following the fall of Napoleon. Louis XVIII was recalled from exile by Talleyrand.|--Examples--|the restoration of Andrew's sight|the altar paintings seem in need of restoration|the restoration of capital punishment|published restorations are dodgy, based on single bones|the restoration of a democratic government|Restoration drama|

--Word--|reverse |--Type--|verb, adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Move backwards.|Cause (a vehicle) to move backwards.|(of an engine) work in a contrary direction.|Make (something) the opposite of what it was.|Exchange (the position or function) of two people or things.|Revoke or annul (a judgement, sentence, or decree made by a lower court or authority)|Turn (something) the other way round or up or inside out.|Make (type or a design) appear as white in a block of solid colour or a half-tone.|Going in or turned towards the direction opposite to that previously stated.|Operating, behaving, or ordered in a way contrary or opposite to that which is usual or expected.|(of a voltage applied to a semiconductor junction) in the direction which does not allow significant current to flow.|Denoting a fault in which a relative downward movement occurred in the strata on the underside of the fault plane.|A complete change of direction or action.|Reverse gear on a motor vehicle; the position of a gear lever or selector corresponding to this.|A play in which a player reverses the direction of attack by passing the ball to a teammate moving in the opposite direction.|The opposite to that previously stated.|An adverse change of fortune; a setback or defeat.|The opposite side or face to the observer.|A left-hand page of an open book, or the back of a loose document.|The side of a coin or medal bearing the value or secondary design.|The design or inscription on the reverse of a coin or medal.|--Examples--|the lorry reversed into the back of a bus|she reversed the car into a side turn|the ship's engines reversed and cut out altogether|the damage done to the ozone layer may be reversed|the experimenter and the subject reversed roles and the experiment was repeated|the court reversed his conviction|after completing a row of leaves or flowers I have reversed the pattern|their press ads had a headline reversed out of the illustration|the trend appears to be going in the reverse direction|indiscriminate bombing had a reverse effect on popular morale|the gall actuates a reverse of photosynthesis|a knob to lock the box in four-wheel drive for reverse|some automatic cars are designed so that Reverse cannot be engaged unless the driver's foot is on the brake pedal|his touchdown came after he had scampered 58 yards on a reverse with McMahon|he didn't feel homesick—quite the reverse|United suffered their heaviest reverse of the season|the address is given on the reverse of this leaflet|

--Word--|reserval |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action or fact of reserving something; reservation.|--Examples--|
--Word--|reservation |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of reserving something.|An arrangement whereby something, especially a seat or room, is reserved for a particular person.|(in church use) the practice of retaining a portion of the consecrated elements after Mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.|An expression of doubt qualifying overall approval of a plan or statement.|An area of land set aside for occupation by North American Indians or Australian Aborigines.|A right or interest retained in an estate being conveyed.|(in the Roman Catholic Church) the action of a superior of reserving to himself the power of absolution.|A right reserved to the Pope of nomination to a vacant benefice.|--Examples--|the reservation of positions for non-Americans|do you have a reservation?|some generals voiced reservations about making air strikes|the boy's family live on an Indian reservation|the retention of a right to enter the demised property will be a reservation|
--Word--|reservationist |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A person who lives on a reservation set apart for a particular group, especially American Indians.|A person holding or advocating the view that certain reservations should be made with regard to the Treaty of Versailles (especially in relation to the proposed establishment of the League of Nations) before it could be ratified by the United States. Now historical.|A person who makes reservations for customers at an airline, restaurant, etc.|That is a reservationist; holding or advocating the views of the reservationists. Now historical.|--Examples--|

--Word--|reservatory |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A place in which water is collected; a reservoir; a cistern, a tank. Also (occasionally): a receptacle for any liquid.|Chiefly Law. Having the effect of reserving something.|--Examples--|
--Word--|reserve |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Retain for future use.|Use or engage in something only in or at (a particular circumstance or time)|(in church use) retain (a portion of the consecrated elements) after Mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.|Retain or hold (a right or entitlement), especially by formal or legal stipulation.|Arrange for (a room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person.|Refrain from delivering (a judgement or decision) without due consideration or evidence.|A supply of a commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required.|Funds kept available by a bank, company, or government.|A part of a company's profits added to capital rather than paid as a dividend.|A body of troops withheld from action to reinforce or protect others, or additional to the regular forces and available in an emergency.|A member of the military reserve.|An extra player who is a possible substitute in a team.|The second-choice team.|A place set aside for special use.|A reservation for an indigenous people.|A protected area for wildlife.|A lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression.|A feeling of doubt qualifying acceptance of a person, statement, or plan.|(in the decoration of ceramics or textiles) an area in which the original material or background colour remains visible.|--Examples--|roll out half the dough and reserve the other half|Japanese food has been presented as expensive and reserved for special occasions|the editor reserves the right to edit letters|a place was reserved for her in the front row|I'll reserve my views on his ability until he's played again|Australia has major coal, gas, and uranium reserves|foreign exchange reserves|the bank built up a cash reserve of £2bn to meet any run on the bank once the loss was revealed|the men were stationed as a central reserve ready to be transported wherever necessary|the army began calling up reserves for combat training|he was reserve hooker for the World Cup team|playing in the first team has been a big step up after the reserves|a reserve was allocated to the tribe on Bear Island|part of the marshes has been managed to create a splendid reserve full of birds|she smiled and some of her natural reserve melted|she trusted him without reserve|

--Word--|reserver |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|--Examples--|
--Word--|reserver |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|--Examples--|
--Word--|reserve |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Retain for future use.|Use or engage in something only in or at (a particular circumstance or time)|(in church use) retain (a portion of the consecrated elements) after Mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.|Retain or hold (a right or entitlement), especially by formal or legal stipulation.|Arrange for (a room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person.|Refrain from delivering (a judgement or decision) without due consideration or evidence.|A supply of a commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required.|Funds kept available by a bank, company, or government.|A part of a company's profits added to capital rather than paid as a dividend.|A body of troops withheld from action to reinforce or protect others, or additional to the regular forces and available in an emergency.|A member of the military reserve.|An extra player who is a possible substitute in a team.|The second-choice team.|A place set aside for special use.|A reservation for an indigenous people.|A protected area for wildlife.|A lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression.|A feeling of doubt qualifying acceptance of a person, statement, or plan.|(in the decoration of ceramics or textiles) an area in which the original material or background colour remains visible.|--Examples--|roll out half the dough and reserve the other half|Japanese food has been presented as expensive and reserved for special occasions|the editor reserves the right to edit letters|a place was reserved for her in the front row|I'll reserve my views on his ability until he's played again|Australia has major coal, gas, and uranium reserves|foreign exchange reserves|the bank built up a cash reserve of £2bn to meet any run on the bank once the loss was revealed|the men were stationed as a central reserve ready to be transported wherever necessary|the army began calling up reserves for combat training|he was reserve hooker for the World Cup team|playing in the first team has been a big step up after the reserves|a reserve was allocated to the tribe on Bear Island|part of the marshes has been managed to create a splendid reserve full of birds|she smiled and some of her natural reserve melted|she trusted him without reserve|

consecrated elements) after Mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.|Retain or hold (a right or entitlement), especially by formal or legal stipulation.|Arrange for (a room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person.|Refrain from delivering (a judgement or decision) without due consideration or evidence.|A supply of a commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required.|Funds kept available by a bank, company, or government.|A part of a company's profits added to capital rather than paid as a dividend.|A body of troops withheld from action to reinforce or protect others, or additional to the regular forces and available in an emergency.|A member of the military reserve.|An extra player who is a possible substitute in a team.|The second-choice team.|A place set aside for special use.|A reservation for an indigenous people.|A protected area for wildlife.|A lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression.|A feeling of doubt qualifying acceptance of a person, statement, or plan.|(in the decoration of ceramics or textiles) an area in which the original material or background colour remains visible.|--Examples--|roll out half the dough and reserve the other half|Japanese food has been presented as expensive and reserved for special occasions|the editor reserves the right to edit letters|a place was reserved for her in the front row|I'll reserve my views on his ability until he's played again|Australia has major coal, gas, and uranium reserves|foreign exchange reserves|the bank built up a cash reserve of £2bn to meet any run on the bank once the loss was revealed|the men were stationed as a central reserve ready to be transported wherever necessary|the army began calling up reserves for combat training|he was reserve hooker for the World Cup team|playing in the first team has been a big step up after the reserves|a reserve was allocated to the tribe on Bear Island|part of the marshes has been managed to create a splendid reserve full of birds|she smiled and some of her natural reserve melted|she trusted him without reserve|

--Word--|reservoir |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A large natural or artificial lake used as a source of water supply.|A supply or source of something.|A place where fluid collects, especially in rock strata or in the body.|A receptacle or part of a machine designed to hold fluid.|A population, tissue, etc. which is chronically infested with the causative agent of a disease and can act as a source of further infection.|--Examples--|the more water we use, the more land has to be flooded for reservoirs|Scotland has always had a fine reservoir of comic talent|big oil reservoirs are becoming harder to find|if all three colours overlap then a black dot is printed from the black ink reservoir|there is a vast reservoir of herpes infection in the community|

--Word--|residency |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The fact of living in a place.|A residential post held by a writer, musician, or artist, typically for teaching purposes.|The official residence of the Governor General's representative or other government agent, especially at the court of an Indian state.|An organization of intelligence agents in a foreign country.|A musician's regular engagement at a club or other venue.|A period of specialized medical training in a hospital; the position of a resident.|--Examples--|a government ruling confirmed the returning refugees' right to residency|the photographs were taken in East London during an artist-in-school residency|he made contact with the KGB residency in Aden|he saw me at a folk club where I was doing the residency one Sunday night|

--Word--|resident |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A person who lives somewhere permanently or on a long-term basis.|A bird, butterfly, or other animal of a species that does not migrate.|A guest in a hotel who stays for one or more nights.|A pupil who boards at a boarding school.|A British government agent in any semi-independent state, especially the Governor General's agent at the court of an Indian state.|An intelligence agent in a foreign country.|A medical graduate engaged in specialized practice under supervision in a hospital.|Living somewhere on a long-term basis.|Having quarters on the premises of one's work.|Attached to and working regularly for a particular institution.|(of a bird, butterfly or other animal) remaining in an area throughout the year; non-migratory.|(of a computer program, file, etc.) immediately available in computer memory, rather than having to be loaded from elsewhere.|--Examples--|it was a beautiful hamlet with just 100 residents|arctic residents are joined annually by long-distance migrants|the hotel restaurant is open to residents and guests of residents|he has been resident in Brazil for a long time|resident farm workers|the film studio needed a resident historian|resident mute swans and wintering Bewick's swans|an intangible computer program resident on a magnetic disk|the ability to load memory-resident programs|

--Word--|residual |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Remaining after the greater part or quantity has gone.|(of a quantity) left after other items have been subtracted.|(of a physical state or property) remaining after the removal of or present in the absence of a causative agent.|(of an experimental or arithmetical error) not accounted for or eliminated.|(of a soil or other deposit) formed in situ by weathering.|A quantity remaining after other things have been subtracted or allowed for.|A difference between a value measured in a scientific experiment and the theoretical or true value.|A portion of rocky or high ground remaining after erosion.|A royalty paid to a performer, writer, etc. for a repeat of a play, television show, etc.|The resale value of a new car or other item at a specified time after purchase, expressed as a percentage of its purchase price.|--Examples--|the withdrawal of residual occupying forces|residual income after tax and mortgage payments|residual stenosis|the Keynesian component is clearly a residual which is arrived at by subtracting the natural and classical components from overall unemployment|the eroded residuals of reefs built in relation to earlier, higher sea levels|she has been awarded more than $4.5 million in residuals and profits from the highly successful television show|the federation wants car tax taken out over five years to avoid residuals being hit|

--Word--|residue |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A small amount of something that remains after the main part has gone or been taken or used.|A substance that remains after a process such as combustion or evaporation.|The part of an estate that is left after the payment of charges, debts, and bequests.|--Examples--|the fine residue left after the sorting of tea|the residue of the country's colonial past|the ash was a residue from coal-fired power stations|the residue of the estate was divided equally among the cousins|
--Word--|residue |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A small amount of something that remains after the main part has gone or been taken or used.|A substance that remains after a process such as combustion or evaporation.|The part of an estate that is left after the payment of charges, debts, and bequests.|--Examples--|the fine residue left after the sorting of tea|the residue of the country's colonial past|the ash was a residue from coal-fired power stations|the residue of the estate was divided equally among the cousins|

--Word--|resistment |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Resistance.|--Examples--|
--Word--|resistment |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Resistance.|--Examples--|
--Word--|resistance |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The refusal to accept or comply with something.|The use of force or violence to oppose someone or something.|A secret organization resisting authority, especially in an occupied country.|The underground movement formed in France during the Second World War to fight the German occupying forces and the Vichy government.|The ability not to be affected by something, especially adversely.|Lack of sensitivity to a drug, insecticide, etc., especially as a result of continued exposure or genetic change.|The impeding or stopping effect exerted by one material thing on another.|The degree to which a substance or device opposes the passage of an electric current, causing energy dissipation. By Ohm's law resistance (measured in ohms) is equal to the voltage divided by the current.|A resistor or other circuit component which opposes the passage of an electric current.|--Examples--|they displayed a narrow-minded resistance to change|government forces were unable to crush guerrilla-style resistance|she put up no resistance to being led away|he went underground and joined the resistance|some of us have a lower resistance to cold than others|many insects show resistance to at least one chemical|air resistance was reduced by streamlining|
--Word--|resistance |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The refusal to accept or comply with something.|The use of force or violence to oppose someone or something.|A secret organization resisting authority, especially in an occupied country.|The underground movement formed in France during the Second World War to fight the German occupying forces and the Vichy government.|The ability not to be affected by something, especially adversely.|Lack of sensitivity to a drug, insecticide, etc., especially as a result of continued exposure or genetic change.|The impeding or stopping effect exerted by one material thing on another.|The degree to which a substance or device opposes the passage of an electric current, causing energy dissipation. By Ohm's law resistance (measured in ohms) is equal to the voltage divided by the current.|A resistor or other circuit component which opposes the passage of an electric current.|--Examples--|they displayed a narrow-minded resistance to change|government forces were unable to crush guerrilla-style resistance|she put up no resistance to being led away|he went underground and joined the resistance|some of us have a lower resistance to cold than others|many insects show resistance to at least one chemical|air resistance was reduced by streamlining|
--Word--|resistant |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Offering resistance to something or someone.|Denoting starch that is not easily broken down by enzymes within the body and is therefore minimally absorbed during digestion.|--Examples--|some of the old Churches are resistant to change|a water-resistant adhesive|cooked rice, like bread, contains a useful amount of resistant starch, which acts like fibre in the digestive system|

--Word--|Resnais, Alain |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1922–2014), French film director. One of the foremost directors of the nouvelle vague, he used experimental techniques to explore memory and time. Notable films: Hiroshima mon amour (1959) and L'Année dernière à Marienbad (1961).|--Examples--|

--Word--|resolution |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A firm decision to do or not to do something.|A formal expression of opinion or intention agreed on by a legislative body or other formal meeting, typically after taking a vote.|The quality of being determined or resolute.|The action of solving a problem or contentious matter.|The passing of a discord into a concord during the course of changing harmony.|The disappearance of a symptom or condition.|The process of reducing or separating something into constituent parts or components.|The replacing of a single force or other vector quantity by two or more jointly equivalent to it.|The smallest interval measurable by a telescope or other scientific instrument; the resolving power.|The degree of detail visible in a photographic or television image.|The conversion of something abstract into another form.|The substitution of two short syllables for one long one.|--Examples--|she kept her resolution not to see Anne any more|a New Year's resolution|the conference passed two resolutions|he handled the last British actions of the war with resolution|the peaceful resolution of all disputes|a successful resolution to the problem|tension is released by the resolution from the dominant to the tonic chord|complete remission was defined as resolution of clinical evidence of disease|a high-resolution monitor|the gradual resolution of an uncertain feeling into a named emotion|

--Word--|resolutioner |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Scottish History. Usually with capital initial. A supporter of the resolutions passed by the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland in 1650 and 1651 calling for the discontinuation of legal sanctions against some of those who had sought an accommodation with Charles I. Usually in plural.|Generally. A person who formulates or supports a resolution. rare.|A person who makes a (New Year's) resolution; = resolutionist.|--Examples--|
--Word--|resolutionist |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who formulates or supports a resolution. Compare resolutioner. Now rare.|A person who makes a (New Year's) resolution.|--Examples--|

--Word--|resolve |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Settle or find a solution to (a problem or contentious matter)|Cause (a symptom or condition) to heal or subside.|(of a symptom or condition) heal or subside.|(with reference to a discord) pass or cause to pass into a concord during the course of harmonic change.|Decide firmly on a course of action.|(of a legislative body or other formal meeting) make a decision by a formal vote.|Separate or cause to be separated into constituent parts or components.|Reduce a subject, statement, etc. by mental analysis into (separate elements or a more elementary form)|Analyse (a force or velocity) into components acting in particular directions.|(of something seen at a distance) turn into a different form when seen more clearly.|(of optical or photographic equipment) separate or distinguish between (closely adjacent objects)|Separately distinguish (peaks in a graph or spectrum).|Firm determination to do something.|A formal resolution by a legislative body or public meeting.|--Examples--|the firm aims to resolve problems within 30 days|endoscopic biliary drainage can rapidly resolve jaundice|symptoms resolved after a median of four weeks|dissonant notes resolve conventionally by rising or falling to form part of a new chord|you would not want to resolve a melodic line on to the minor sixth interval|she resolved to ring Dana as soon as she got home|the executive resolved that a strike would be detrimental to all concerned|the conference resolved to support an alliance|alpha-zein is often resolved into two major size components|the Labyrinth's design resolves into a number of distinct functional areas|the ability to resolve facts into their legal categories|the orange light resolved itself into four roadwork lanterns|Hubble was able to resolve six variable stars in M31|she received information that strengthened her resolve|

--Word--|resonance |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The quality in a sound of being deep, full, and reverberating.|The power to evoke enduring images, memories, and emotions.|The reinforcement or prolongation of sound by reflection from a surface or by the synchronous vibration of a neighbouring object.|The condition in which an electric circuit or device produces the largest possible response to an applied oscillating signal.|The condition in which an object or system is subjected to an oscillating force having a frequency close to its own natural frequency.|The occurrence of a simple ratio between the periods of revolution of two bodies about a single primary.|The property of having a molecular structure which cannot adequately be represented by a single structural formula but is a composite of two or more structures of higher energy.|A short-lived subatomic particle that is an excited state of a more stable particle.|--Examples--|the resonance of his voice|the concepts lose their emotional resonance|
--Word--|resonance |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The quality in a sound of being deep, full, and reverberating.|The power to evoke enduring images, memories, and emotions.|The reinforcement or prolongation of sound by reflection from a surface or by the synchronous vibration of a neighbouring object.|The condition in which an electric circuit or device produces the largest possible response to an applied oscillating signal.|The condition in which an object or system is subjected to an oscillating force having a frequency close to its own natural frequency.|The occurrence of a simple ratio between the periods of revolution of two bodies about a single primary.|The property of having a molecular structure which cannot adequately be represented by a single structural formula but is a composite of two or more structures of higher energy.|A short-lived subatomic particle that is an excited state of a more stable particle.|--Examples--|the resonance of his voice|the concepts lose their emotional resonance|

--Word--|resonancy |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Resonance.|--Examples--|
--Word--|resonant |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|(of sound) deep, clear, and continuing to sound or reverberate.|(of a place) filled or resounding with (a sound)|Having the ability to evoke enduring images, memories, or emotions.|(of a room, musical instrument, or hollow body) tending to reinforce or prolong sounds, especially by synchronous vibration.|Relating to or bringing about resonance in a circuit, atom, or other object.|(of a colour) enhancing or enriching another colour or colours by contrast.|--Examples--|a full-throated and resonant guffaw|alpine valleys resonant with the sound of church bells|the prints are resonant with traditions of Russian folk art and story|the sound of these instruments, played in a resonant room, is unforgettable|the sound is produced by striking resonant little metal bars|resonant absorption of radiation|the resonant reds, greens, and browns typical of Ribera's palette|

--Word--|resort |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A place that is frequented for holidays or recreation or for a particular purpose.|The tendency of a place to be frequented by many people.|The action of resorting to a course of action in a difficult situation.|A course of action that is resorted to.|Turn to and adopt (a course of action, especially an extreme or undesirable one) so as to resolve a difficult situation.|Go often or in large numbers to.|--Examples--|a seaside resort|a health resort|places of public resort|territorial questions must not be settled by resort to violence|workers may regard an all-out strike as a measure of last resort|her only resort is a private operation|the duke was prepared to resort to force if negotiation failed|local authorities have a duty to provide adequate sites for gypsies residing in or resorting to their areas|

--Word--|resource |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A stock or supply of money, materials, staff, and other assets that can be drawn on by a person or organization in order to function effectively.|A country's collective means of supporting itself or becoming wealthier, as represented by its reserves of minerals, land, and other natural assets.|A source of help or information.|Available assets.|An action or strategy which may be adopted in adverse circumstances.|Personal attributes and capabilities regarded as able to help or sustain one in adverse circumstances.|The ability to find clever ways to overcome difficulties; resourcefulness.|The possibility of aid or assistance.|A leisure occupation.|Provide with resources.|--Examples--|local authorities complained that they lacked resources|Japan's exploitation of commercially important marine resources|census records are an invaluable resource for the historian|the database could be used as a reference and teaching resource|sometimes anger is the only resource left in a situation like this|we had been left very much to our own resources|a man of resource|the flower of the French army was lost without resource|a strategy which ensures that primary health care workers are adequately resourced|
--Word--|resourceful |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having the ability to find quick and clever ways to overcome difficulties.|--Examples--|he maintained her reputation for being a resourceful problem-solver|you will become stronger and more resourceful in the face of adversity|
--Word--|resourcefully |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|--Examples--|
--Word--|resourcefulness |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The ability to find quick and clever ways to overcome difficulties.|--Examples--|his films show remarkable technical resourcefulness|

--Word--|resource |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A stock or supply of money, materials, staff, and other assets that can be drawn on by a person or organization in order to function effectively.|A country's collective means of supporting itself or becoming wealthier, as represented by its reserves of minerals, land, and other natural assets.|A source of help or information.|Available assets.|An action or strategy which may be adopted in adverse circumstances.|Personal attributes and capabilities regarded as able to help or sustain one in adverse circumstances.|The ability to find clever ways to overcome difficulties; resourcefulness.|The possibility of aid or assistance.|A leisure occupation.|Provide with resources.|--Examples--|local authorities complained that they lacked resources|Japan's exploitation of commercially important marine resources|census records are an invaluable resource for the historian|the database could be used as a reference and teaching resource|sometimes anger is the only resource left in a situation like this|we had been left very much to our own resources|a man of resource|the flower of the French army was lost without resource|a strategy which ensures that primary health care workers are adequately resourced|

--Word--|respect |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A feeling of deep admiration for someone or something elicited by their abilities, qualities, or achievements.|The state of being admired or respected.|A person's polite greetings.|Used to express the speaker's approval of someone or something.|Due regard for the feelings, wishes, or rights of others.|A particular aspect, point, or detail.|Admire (someone or something) deeply, as a result of their abilities, qualities, or achievements.|Have due regard for (someone's feelings, wishes, or rights)|Avoid harming or interfering with.|Agree to recognize and abide by (a legal requirement)|--Examples--|the director had a lot of respect for Douglas as an actor|his first chance in over fifteen years to regain respect in the business|give my respects to their Excellencies|respect to Hill for a truly non-superficial piece on the techno scene|young people's lack of respect for their parents|the government's record in this respect is a mixed one|she was respected by everyone she worked with|I respected his views|it is incumbent upon all hill users to respect the environment|the crown and its ministers ought to respect the ordinary law|

--Word--|response |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A verbal or written answer.|An answer to a question in a test, questionnaire, etc.|A part of a religious liturgy said or sung by a congregation in answer to a minister or cantor.|A reaction to something.|An excitation of a nerve impulse caused by a change or event; a physical reaction to a specific stimulus or situation.|The way in which a mechanical or electrical device responds to a stimulus or stimuli.|A bid made in answer to one's partner's preceding bid.|--Examples--|there was laughter at his response to the question|we received 400 applications in response to one job ad|table 3.1 shows the mean number of correct responses given by each age group|an extended, jazzy piano solo drew the biggest response from the crowd|an Honours degree course in Japanese has been established in response to an increasing demand|we unwittingly induce Pavlovian-type responses in dogs by establishing a rigid routine for feeding|there is considerable species variation in the stomach's response to alcohol|the throttle response from the 1870 cc engine is almost petrol sharp|

--Word--|response |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A verbal or written answer.|An answer to a question in a test, questionnaire, etc.|A part of a religious liturgy said or sung by a congregation in answer to a minister or cantor.|A reaction to something.|An excitation of a nerve impulse caused by a change or event; a physical reaction to a specific stimulus or situation.|The way in which a mechanical or electrical device responds to a stimulus or stimuli.|A bid made in answer to one's partner's preceding bid.|--Examples--|there was laughter at his response to the question|we received 400 applications in response to one job ad|table 3.1 shows the mean number of correct responses given by each age group|an extended, jazzy piano solo drew the biggest response from the crowd|an Honours degree course in Japanese has been established in response to an increasing demand|we unwittingly induce Pavlovian-type responses in dogs by establishing a rigid routine for feeding|there is considerable species variation in the stomach's response to alcohol|the throttle response from the 1870 cc engine is almost petrol sharp|
--Word--|responsibility |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The state or fact of having a duty to deal with something or of having control over someone.|The state or fact of being accountable or to blame for something.|A moral obligation to behave correctly towards or in respect of.|The opportunity or ability to act independently and take decisions without authorization.|A thing which one is required to do as part of a job, role, or legal obligation.|--Examples--|a true leader takes responsibility for their team and helps them achieve goals|the group has claimed responsibility for a string of murders|individuals have a responsibility to control their behaviour|we expect individuals to take on more responsibility|he will take over the responsibilities of Overseas Director|

--Word--|responsible |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having an obligation to do something, or having control over or care for someone, as part of one's job or role.|Having to report to (a superior) and be answerable to them for one's actions.|Being the primary cause of something and so able to be blamed or credited for it.|Morally accountable for one's behaviour.|(of a job or position) involving important duties, independent decision-making, or control over others.|Capable of being trusted.|--Examples--|the cabinet minister responsible for Education|the Prime Minister and cabinet are responsible to Parliament|Gooch was responsible for 198 of his side's 542 runs|the progressive emergence of the child as a responsible being|she had risen rapidly to a high and responsible position in the civil service|a responsible adult|

--Word--|restoration |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of returning something to a former owner, place, or condition.|The process of restoring a building, work of art, etc. to its original condition.|The reinstatement of a previous practice, right, or situation.|A structure provided to replace or repair dental tissue so as to restore its form and function, such as a filling, crown, or bridge.|A model or drawing representing the supposed original form of an extinct animal, ruined building, etc.|The return of a monarch to a throne, a head of state to government, or a regime to power.|The re-establishment of Charles II as King of England in 1660. After the death of Oliver Cromwell in 1658, his son Richard (1626–1712) proved incapable of maintaining the Protectorate, and General Monck organized the king's return from exile.|The period following the Restoration of Charles II.|The restoration of the Bourbon monarchy in France in 1814, following the fall of Napoleon. Louis XVIII was recalled from exile by Talleyrand.|--Examples--|the restoration of Andrew's sight|the altar paintings seem in need of restoration|the restoration of capital punishment|published restorations are dodgy, based on single bones|the restoration of a democratic government|Restoration drama|

--Word--|rest |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Cease work or movement in order to relax, sleep, or recover strength.|Allow to be inactive in order to regain strength or health.|(of a body) lie buried.|Used euphemistically by actors to indicate that they are out of work.|Leave (a player) out of a team temporarily.|(of a problem or subject) be left without further investigation or discussion.|Allow (land) to lie fallow.|Be placed or supported so as to stay in a specified position.|Place (something) so that it is supported in a specified position.|(of a look) alight or be steadily directed on.|Be based on; depend on.|Place hope, trust, or confidence on or in.|Be the responsibility of or belong to a specified person.|Conclude presentation of either party's case in a suit or prosecution.|An instance or period of resting.|A motionless state.|An interval of silence of a specified duration.|The sign denoting a musical rest.|A pause in speech or verse.|An object that is used to support something.|A support or hook for a telephone receiver when not in use.|A support for a cue in billiards or snooker.|--Examples--|he needed to rest after the feverish activity|I'm going to rest up before travelling to England|her friend read to her while she rested her eyes|the king's body rested in his tomb|she was an actress but doing domestic work while she was resting|both men were rested for the cup final|the council has urged the planning committee not to allow the matter to rest|the field should be grazed or rested|her elbow was resting on the arm of the sofa|he rested a hand on her shoulder|his eyes rested briefly on the boy|the country's security rested on its alliances|she rested her hopes in her attorney|the final say rests with the regional assemblies|the prosecution rests|you look as though you need a rest|a couple of days of complete rest|the car accelerates rapidly from rest|a shoulder rest|carefully the receiver was replaced on the rest|

--Word--|resuing |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A method of mining used for narrow veins, in which the rock wall adjacent to the vein is removed by cutting or excavating in steps or layer by layer (stoping), allowing the ore to be extracted in a cleaner condition.|--Examples--|
--Word--|result |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A thing that is caused or produced by something else; a consequence or outcome.|A favourable outcome of an undertaking or contest.|The outcome of a business's trading over a given period, expressed as a statement of profit or loss.|A final score, mark, or placing in a sporting event or examination.|An item of information obtained by experiment or some other scientific method; a quantity or formula obtained by calculation.|Occur or follow as the consequence of something.|Have (a specified outcome)|--Examples--|the tower collapsed as a result of safety violations|different approaches have been tried with somewhat mixed results|determination and persistence guarantee results|if we can get a result in that game we might qualify|oil companies have reported better results|exam results|it was a great result for us|the results are evaluated by the researcher|anger may result from an argument|talks in July had resulted in stalemate|

--Word--|retain |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Continue to have (something); keep possession of.|Not abolish or alter; maintain.|Keep in one's memory.|Absorb and continue to hold (a substance)|Keep (something) in place; hold fixed.|Keep (someone) engaged in one's service.|Secure the services of (a barrister) with a preliminary payment.|--Examples--|Labour retained the seat|built in 1830, the house retains many of its original features|the rights of defendants must be retained|I retained a few French words and phrases|limestone is known to retain water|remove the retaining bar|he has been retained as a freelance|retain a barrister to handle the client's business|

--Word--|retainder |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Law. The action or fact of retaining money, goods, or property for oneself; an instance of this.|A token or badge given to a follower by a sovereign or noble as a sign of his retainership. Now rare (historical after 16th cent.).|Engagement of a person as a servant or follower; an instance of this. Also: maintenance by a sovereign or noble of a company of followers or dependants, who give (especially military) service in return for money, patronage, or protection.|--Examples--|
--Word--|retain |--Type--|verb|--Meanings--|Continue to have (something); keep possession of.|Not abolish or alter; maintain.|Keep in one's memory.|Absorb and continue to hold (a substance)|Keep (something) in place; hold fixed.|Keep (someone) engaged in one's service.|Secure the services of (a barrister) with a preliminary payment.|--Examples--|Labour retained the seat|built in 1830, the house retains many of its original features|the rights of defendants must be retained|I retained a few French words and phrases|limestone is known to retain water|remove the retaining bar|he has been retained as a freelance|retain a barrister to handle the client's business|
--Word--|retainer |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A thing that holds something in place.|An appliance for keeping a loose tooth, an orthodontic prosthesis, or orthodontically aligned teeth in place.|A fee paid in advance to someone, especially a barrister, in order to secure their services for use when required.|A reduced rent paid to retain accommodation during a period of non-occupancy.|A servant, especially one who has worked for a person or family for a long time.|--Examples--|a guitar string retainer|he's on a retainer as a consultant|faithful family retainers|

--Word--|retinaculum |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Anatomy. A structure that holds (or appears to hold) something in place; specifically †(a) = proligerous disc (obsolete); (b) a ligamentous band retaining tendons in place, especially in the region of the wrist and ankle (frequently with distinguishing English or scientific Latin word or words).|An arrangement of hooks, folds, or bristles, which interlocks the fore- and hindwings of various insects during flight; specifically that on the underside of the forewing in many butterflies and moths, engaging with a frenulum on the hindwing.|In collembolans: a fused pair of appendages which hold back the furcula before releasing it for a spring.|In plants of the acanthus family: each of the hooklike projections (modified funicles) on which the seeds are attached and which aid in their ejection; a jaculator.|In orchids: the sticky gland of the rostellum to which the stalk of each of the pollinia (pollen masses) adheres; a viscidium; now rare. In asclepiads: the armlike process borne by each of the pollinia to aid pollen transfer.|--Examples--|

--Word--|retire |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Leave one's job and cease to work, typically on reaching the normal age for leaving service.|Compel (an employee) to leave their job, especially before they have reached retirement age.|(of a player) cease to participate in competitive sport.|(of a sports player) withdraw from a race or match as a result of accident or injury.|Put out (a batter); cause (a side) to end a turn at bat.|Withdraw to or from a particular place.|Go to bed.|(of a jury) leave the courtroom to decide the verdict of a trial.|(of a military force) retreat from an enemy or an attacking position.|Order (a military force) to retreat.|Withdraw (a bill or note) from circulation or currency.|Pay off or cancel (a debt)|A movement in which one leg is raised at right angles to the body until the toe is in line with the knee of the supporting leg.|--Examples--|he retired from the Navy in 1986|the Home Office retired him|he retired from football several years ago|he was forced to retire with a damaged oil tank|Stewart retired hurt|Dopson retired twelve batters in a row|she retired into the bathroom|everyone retired early that night|the judge finished his summing up and the jury retired|lack of numbers compelled the British force to retire|the general retired all his troops|the debt is to be retired from state gaming-tax receipts|

--Word--|retorsion |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A backwards turn or bend; a twist; the fact of being twisted or bent backwards.|Originally: †the act of giving something back or in return (obsolete). Later: the action or an act of retorting an argument, charge, etc.|Return for something done; retaliation. Now chiefly: (International Law) retaliation within the law by a state on another's subjects; an instance of this.|--Examples--|
--Word--|retort |--Type--|verb, noun, noun, verb|--Meanings--|Say something in answer to a remark, typically in a sharp, angry, or witty manner.|Repay (an insult or injury)|Turn (an insult or accusation) back on the person who has issued it.|Use (an opponent's argument) against them.|A sharp, angry, or witty reply.|A container or furnace for carrying out a chemical process on a large or industrial scale.|A glass container with a long neck, used in distilling liquids and other chemical operations.|Heat in a retort in order to separate or purify.|--Examples--|No need to be rude, retorted Isabel|he retorted that this was nonsense|it was now his time to retort the humiliation|he was resolute to retort the charge of treason on his foes|the answer they make to us may very easily be retorted|she opened her mouth to make a suitably cutting retort|gas was made by baking coal in airtight retorts|a laboratory full of bubbling retorts and crackling electrical equipment|the raw shale is retorted at four crude oil works|

--Word--|retreat |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|(of an army) withdraw from enemy forces as a result of their superior power or after a defeat.|Move back or withdraw.|Withdraw to a quiet or secluded place.|Change one's mind or plans as a result of criticism or difficulty.|(of shares) decline in value.|Move (a piece) back from a forward or threatened position on the board.|An act of moving back or withdrawing.|An act of changing one's mind or plans as a result of criticism or difficulty.|A signal for a military force to withdraw.|A military musical ceremony carried out at sunset, originating in the playing of drums and bugles to tell soldiers to return to camp for the night.|A quiet or secluded place in which one can rest and relax.|A period or place of seclusion for the purposes of prayer and meditation.|A decline in the value of shares.|--Examples--|the French retreated in disarray|it becomes so hot that the lizards retreat into the shade|the ice retreated during warmer periods called interglacials|after the funeral he retreated to Scotland|his proposals were clearly unreasonable and he was forced to retreat|the company reported healthy figures but the shares retreated|a speedy retreat|the army was in retreat|the trade unions made a retreat from their earlier position|the bugle sounded a retreat|their country retreat in Ireland|the bishop is away on his annual retreat|before his ordination he went into retreat|a gloomy stock market forecast sent share prices into a rapid retreat|

--Word--|retreatism |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Withdrawal, especially from society; (Sociology) the abandonment or rejection of culturally approved goals and the institutionalized means of attaining them, induced by a perceived inability to achieve those goals.|Advocacy of a policy of (typically military) retreat; a policy characterized by the advocacy of retreat.|--Examples--|

--Word--|retrieve |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Get or bring (something) back from somewhere.|(of a dog) find and bring back (game that has been shot)|Reel or bring in a fishing line.|Find or extract (information stored in a computer)|Recall (something)|Put right or improve (an unwelcome situation)|An act of retrieving something, especially game that has been shot.|An act of reeling or drawing in a fishing line.|The possibility of recovery.|--Examples--|I was sent to retrieve the balls from his garden|Steven stooped and retrieved his hat|labradors are used to retrieve the birds after the flush|when he reaches the breakers, with you retrieving furiously, he'll probably change course|other features include the ability to store, update, retrieve, and print your data|the police hope to encourage him to retrieve forgotten memories|he made one last desperate attempt to retrieve the situation|watch the dog make the long retrieves|the chances are that the retrieve will bring your bait through an area of unfished water|he ruined himself beyond retrieve|
