--Word--|root |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment to the rest of the plant via numerous branches and fibres.|The persistent underground part of a plant, especially when fleshy and enlarged and used as a vegetable, e.g. a turnip or carrot.|Any plant grown for its root.|The embedded part of a bodily organ or structure such as a hair, tooth, or nail.|The part of a thing attaching it to a greater or more fundamental whole; the end or base.|The basic cause, source, or origin of something.|Family, ethnic, or cultural origins.|Denoting or relating to something from a particular ethnic or cultural origin, especially a non-Western one.|(in biblical use) a scion; a descendant.|A morpheme, not necessarily surviving as a word in itself, from which words have been made by the addition of prefixes or suffixes or by other modification.|The fundamental note of a chord.|A number or quantity that when multiplied by itself, typically a specified number of times, gives a specified number or quantity.|A value of an unknown quantity satisfying a given equation.|A user account with full and unrestricted access to a system.|An act of sexual intercourse.|A sexual partner of a specified ability.|Cause (a plant or cutting) to grow roots.|(of a plant or cutting) establish roots.|Establish deeply and firmly.|Have as an origin or cause.|Cause (someone) to stand immobile through fear or amazement.|Gain access to the root account of (a smartphone or computer)|Have sexual intercourse with.|Exhaust (someone) or frustrate their efforts.|--Examples--|cacti have deep and spreading roots|a tree root|root growth|you should never wash roots before storing|roots like beet and carrot cannot be transplanted|her hair was fairer at the roots|a little lever near the root of the barrel|they disappeared from sight behind the root of the crag|money is the root of all evil|jealousy was at the root of it|the root cause of the problem|it's always nice to return to my roots|roots music|the root of David|many European words stem from this linguistic root|the root form of the word|in the sequence the roots of the chords drop by fifths|the roots of the equation differ by an integer|make sure that these files can only be accessed by the root user|I need to log in as root on my system to resolve an issue|root your own cuttings from stock plants|large trees had rooted in the canal bank|vegetarianism is rooted in Indian culture|the Latin verb is rooted in an Indo-European word|she found herself rooted to the spot in disbelief|we explained how to manually root almost any Android device|grab a pew—you must be rooted|

a descendant.|A morpheme, not necessarily surviving as a word in itself, from which words have been made by the addition of prefixes or suffixes or by other modification.|The fundamental note of a chord.|A number or quantity that when multiplied by itself, typically a specified number of times, gives a specified number or quantity.|A value of an unknown quantity satisfying a given equation.|A user account with full and unrestricted access to a system.|An act of sexual intercourse.|A sexual partner of a specified ability.|Cause (a plant or cutting) to grow roots.|(of a plant or cutting) establish roots.|Establish deeply and firmly.|Have as an origin or cause.|Cause (someone) to stand immobile through fear or amazement.|Gain access to the root account of (a smartphone or computer)|Have sexual intercourse with.|Exhaust (someone) or frustrate their efforts.|--Examples--|cacti have deep and spreading roots|a tree root|root growth|you should never wash roots before storing|roots like beet and carrot cannot be transplanted|her hair was fairer at the roots|a little lever near the root of the barrel|they disappeared from sight behind the root of the crag|money is the root of all evil|jealousy was at the root of it|the root cause of the problem|it's always nice to return to my roots|roots music|the root of David|many European words stem from this linguistic root|the root form of the word|in the sequence the roots of the chords drop by fifths|the roots of the equation differ by an integer|make sure that these files can only be accessed by the root user|I need to log in as root on my system to resolve an issue|root your own cuttings from stock plants|large trees had rooted in the canal bank|vegetarianism is rooted in Indian culture|the Latin verb is rooted in an Indo-European word|she found herself rooted to the spot in disbelief|we explained how to manually root almost any Android device|grab a pew—you must be rooted|

--Word--|rotation |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action of rotating about an axis or centre.|The conceptual operation of turning a system about an axis.|The passing of a privilege or responsibility to each member of a group in a regularly recurring order.|The growing of different crops in succession on a piece of land to avoid exhausting the soil and to control weeds, pests, and diseases.|The cycle of growth and felling or cutting of trees.|A tour of duty, especially by a medical practitioner in training.|--Examples--|the moon moves in the same direction as the earth's rotation|several solar rotations|it has become common for senior academics to act as heads of department in rotation|traditional practices such as crop rotation|short rotation forestry|a rotation of 60–80 years to provide valuable saw timber|she was completing a rotation in trauma surgery|
--Word--|rotational |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Using or relating to a circular movement about an axis or centre.|Relating to the conceptual operation of turning a system about an axis.|Relating to or denoting a system in which privilege or responsibility is passed to each member of a group in a regularly recurring order.|Relating to or denoting a system of grazing in which animals are grazed successively on different areas of land.|--Examples--|the increased rotational speed of today's disc drives|reward all selected students on a rotational basis|rotational grazing improves production|

--Word--|rot |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|(chiefly of animal or vegetable matter) decay or cause to decay by the action of bacteria and fungi; decompose.|Gradually deteriorate, especially through neglect.|Make fun of; tease.|The process of decaying.|Rotten or decayed matter.|Any of a number of fungal or bacterial diseases that cause tissue deterioration, especially in plants.|Liver rot in sheep.|A process of deterioration; a decline in standards.|Corruption on the part of officials.|Nonsense; rubbish.|--Examples--|the chalets were neglected and their woodwork was rotting away|caries sets in at a weak point and spreads to rot the whole tooth|the education system has been allowed to rot|has anybody been rotting you?|the leaves were turning black with rot|there is enough talent in the team to stop the rot|it was when they moved back to the family home that the rot set in|don't talk rot|Rot! she said with vehemence|

--Word--|rotula |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Anatomy. The patella (kneecap). Now rare.|Astronomy. A mechanical device showing the motion of the sun and moon and their position for each day of the year. More fully astronomical rotula. Now historical.|Zoology. A keyhole urchin or sand dollar of the West African genus Rotula (order Clypeasteroida), having a round, flattened test with deep notches along the edge. Also (in form Rotula): the genus itself.|Each of five radial elements forming part of the oral apparatus (Aristotle's lantern) of echinoids.|A circular structure forming the end of some sponge spicules; = rotule. Also: a wheel-shaped spicule in the integument of certain holothurians. Now rare.|--Examples--|

--Word--|roture |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|In pre-revolutionary France, Canada under the seigneurial system, and certain other places with a polity based on the French feudal system: tenure of land subject to payment of rent as opposed to feudal obligations of homage and personal service; especially in in roture. --Word--|roturier |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A person of low social rank; a commoner; specifically (in pre-revolutionary France) a member of a social class comprising all those not nobles or clergy, i.e. the bourgeois and villeins collectively. Compare roture. Now historical. [In the 19th and early 20th centuries, often implying vulgarity, and the possession of newly acquired wealth.]|In Canada: a person who holds real estate subject to an annual rent paid to a seigneur. Compare roture. Now historical.|Of or characteristic of a roturier; of low social rank; not noble; common.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rough |--Type--|adjective, adverb, noun, verb|--Meanings--|Having an uneven or irregular surface; not smooth or level.|Denoting the face of a tennis or squash racket on which the loops formed from the stringing process project (used as a call when the racket is spun to decide the right to serve first or to choose ends).|(of a person or their behaviour) not gentle; violent or boisterous.|(of an area or occasion) characterized by violent behaviour.|(of weather or the sea) wild and stormy.|Not finished tidily or decoratively; plain and basic.|Put together as a temporary measure; makeshift.|Lacking sophistication or refinement.|Not fully worked out or including every detail.|(of stationery) used for making preliminary notes.|(of a voice) harsh and rasping.|(of wine or another alcoholic drink) sharp or harsh in taste.|Not exact or precise; approximate.|Difficult and unpleasant or unfair.|Unwell.|In a manner that lacks gentleness; harshly or violently.|A disreputable and violent person.|(on a golf course) longer grass around the fairway and the green.|A preliminary sketch.|An uncut precious stone.|Work or shape (something) in a rough, preliminary fashion.|Produce a preliminary and unfinished version of something.|Make uneven.|Live in discomfort with only basic necessities.|--Examples--|they had to carry the victim across the rough, stony ground|her skin felt dry and rough|pushchairs should be capable of withstanding rough treatment|the workmen hate going to the rough estates|the lifeboat crew braved rough seas to rescue a couple|the customers sat at rough wooden tables|he had one arm in a rough sling|she took care of him in her rough, kindly way|he had a rough draft of his new novel|rough paper|his voice was rough with barely suppressed fury|he refilled the mug with rough cider|they had a rough idea of when the murder took place|it'll cost about £50, at a rough guess|the teachers gave me a rough time because my image didn't fit|the first day of a job is rough on everyone|the altitude had hit her and she was feeling rough|treat 'em rough but treat 'em fair|the rear of the column was attacked by roughs|his second shot lay in the rough|I did a rough to work out the scale of the lettering|miners discovered one of the biggest diamond roughs in history|flat surfaces of wood are roughed down|the engineer roughed out a diagram on his notepad|rough up the icing with a palette knife|she'd had to rough it alone in digs|

--Word--|rouge |--Type--|noun, verb, adjective, noun|--Meanings--|A red powder or cream used as a cosmetic for colouring the cheeks or lips.|Colour with rouge.|Apply rouge to one's cheeks.|(of wine) red.|(in Canadian football) a single point awarded when the receiving team fails to run a kick out of its own end zone.|--Examples--|she wore patches of rouge on her cheeks|her brightly rouged cheeks|she rouged regularly now|
--Word--|rouille |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A Provençal sauce made from pounded red chillies, garlic, breadcrumbs, and other ingredients blended with stock, typically added to bouillabaisse.|--Examples--|croutons and rouille on the side|it's a lusty affair served with a properly pungent rouille|

--Word--|rouky |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Misty, foggy.|--Examples--|
--Word--|roulade |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A dish cooked or served in the form of a roll, typically made from a flat piece of meat, fish, or sponge, spread with a soft filling and rolled up into a spiral.|A florid passage of runs in classical music for a solo virtuoso, especially one sung to one syllable.|--Examples--|Mozart's Constanze sings her defiance in proudly beautiful roulades|

--Word--|roulette |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A gambling game in which a ball is dropped on to a revolving wheel with numbered compartments, the players betting on the number at which the ball comes to rest.|A tool or machine with a revolving toothed wheel, used in engraving or for making slit-shaped perforations between postage stamps.|Make slit-shaped perforations in (paper, especially sheets of postage stamps)|--Examples--|the pages are rouletted next to the binding|

--Word--|Rumeliot |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|(A) Of, relating to, or belonging to Rumelia, a region in the Balkan peninsula formerly ruled by the Ottoman Empire; = Rumelian (b) With reference to the Greek War of Independence: of, relating to, or belonging to that part of Greece corresponding to Aetolia-Acarnania.|(A) A native or inhabitant of Rumelia. (b) With reference to the Greek War of Independence: a person from that part of Greece corresponding to Aetolia-Acarnania.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rounce |--Type--|noun, noun, verb|--Meanings--|A handle used to operate a winch connected to the spit of a hand printing press, by which the carriage is moved in and out.|The winch which is operated by the rounce.|A card game resembling whist, the object of which is to reduce an initial score (of fifteen) to zero by winning tricks.|(In pass.). To incur penalty points in a game of rounce by failing to take a trick after entering a play.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rouncy |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A horse, especially one used for riding; a steed.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rouncival |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|More fully †rouncival pease, rouncival pea. A large variety of garden or field pea. Also (in plural): peas of this variety. Now chiefly historical.|A large, boisterous, or masculine woman. Compare rouncyrare after 17th cent.|--Examples--|
--Word--|round |--Type--|adjective, noun, adverb, preposition, verb|--Meanings--|Shaped like a circle or cylinder.|Having a curved shape like part of the circumference of a circle.|(of a person's shoulders) bent forward from the line of the back.|Shaped like a sphere.|(of a person's body) plump.|Having a curved surface with no sharp projections.|(of a voice) rich and mellow; not harsh.|(of a number) expressed in convenient units rather than exactly, for example to the nearest whole number or multiple of ten.|Used to show that a figure has been completely and exactly reached.|(of a sum of money) considerable.|Not omitting or disguising anything; frank.|A circular piece of something.|A thick disc of beef cut from the haunch as a joint.|An act of visiting a number of people or places in turn.|A regular tour of inspection in which the well-being of those visited is checked.|A journey along a fixed route delivering goods as part of one's job or a job involving such journeys.|Each of a sequence of sessions in a process, typically characterized by development between one session and another.|A division of a contest such as a boxing or wrestling match.|Each of a succession of stages in a competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated.|An act of playing all the holes in a golf course once.|A regularly recurring sequence of activities.|A set of drinks bought for all the members of a group, typically as part of a sequence in which each member in turn buys such a set.|A song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts, each singing the same theme but starting one after another, at the same pitch or in octaves; a simple canon.|A slice of bread.|The quantity of sandwiches made from two slices of bread.|The amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot.|A fixed number of arrows shot from a fixed distance.|So as to rotate or cause rotation; with circular motion.|So as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular centre.|So as to reach everyone in a particular group or area.|So as to rotate and face in the opposite direction.|So as to lead in another direction.|Used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items.|Used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events.|So as to surround someone or something.|Used in stating the girth of something.|So as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving to the other side of something.|Used to convey an ability to navigate or orientate oneself.|Used to convey the idea of visiting someone else.|Used to suggest idle and purposeless motion or activity.|So as to give support and companionship.|On every side of (a focal point)|(of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focus.|So as to encircle (someone or something)|(of a person's arm or arms) partially encircling (another person) as a gesture of affection.|Following an approximately circular route past (a corner or obstacle)|On the other side of (a corner or obstacle)|So as to hit (something) in passing.|So as to cover or take in the whole area of (a place)|Pass and go round (something) so as to move on in a changed direction.|Alter (a number) to one less exact but more convenient for calculations.|Give a round shape to.|Become circular in shape.|Pronounce (a vowel) with the lips narrowed and protruded.|--Examples--|she was seated at a small, round table|round brackets|a round glass ball|the grapes are small and round|he could move quickly despite his round physique|the boulders look round and smooth|his rich, round voice went down well with the listeners|the size of the fleet is given in round numbers|the batsman made a round 100|a round dozen|his business is worth a round sum to me|she berated him in good round terms|cut the pastry into rounds|she did the rounds of her family to say goodbye|the doctor is just making his rounds in the wards|I did a newspaper round|the two sides held three rounds of talks|the FA Cup first round|Eileen enjoys the occasional round of golf|their lives were a daily round of housework and laundry|it's my round|two rounds of toast|the gun can fire 30 rounds a second|a plane circled round overhead|she turned her glass round and round|she paused to glance round admiringly at the décor|he passed round a newspaper cutting|he swung round to face her|it was the last house before the road curved round|the picture shows the pieces the wrong way round|it was he who was attacking her, not the other way round|everyone crowded round|a pool with banks all the way round|the trunk is nine feet round|he made his way round to the back of the building|they went the long way round by the main road|I like pupils to find their own way round|why don't you come round to my flat?|he was driving round aimlessly|if one girl is distraught the others will rally round|the area round the school|with shifting sands all round me|the text is built round real practical examples|he wrapped the blanket round him|she drew a red circle round his name|Angus put an arm round Flora and kissed her|a bus appeared round the corner|Steven parked the car round the corner|if he didn't shut up he might get a clip round the ear|she went round the house and saw that all the windows were barred|the ship rounded the cape and sailed north|we'll round the weight up to the nearest kilo|the committee rounded down the figure|a lathe that rounded chair legs|her eyes rounded in dismay|the actor's uneven attempt to round the vowels of his midwestern twang|
--Word--|roundabout |--Type--|noun, adjective|--Meanings--|A road junction at which traffic moves in one direction round a central island to reach one of the roads converging on it.|A large revolving device in a playground, for children to ride on.|A revolving machine with model horses or cars on which people ride for amusement; a merry-go-round.|Not following a short direct route; circuitous.|Not saying what is meant clearly and directly; circumlocutory.|--Examples--|turn right at the next roundabout|we need to take a roundabout route to throw off any pursuit|in a roundabout way, he was fishing for information|
--Word--|round about |--Type--|phrase|--Meanings--|On all sides or in all directions.|At a point or time approximately equal to.|Approximately.|--Examples--|everything round about was covered with snow|they arrived round about nine|compasses were first added to sundials round about the end of the fourteenth century|we raised round about half a million dollars|round about 10,000 homes were affected|
--Word--|roundaboutly |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|In a roundabout or indirect way.|--Examples--|
--Word--|roundaboutness |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The quality of being roundabout or indirect; especially circuitousness or indirectness of speech or expression; circumlocution.|Economics. A measure of the indirectness of the connection between a capital investment in production and the consequent delivery of a product to a consumer.|--Examples--|
--Word--|round-arch |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Attributive = round-arched.|--Examples--|
--Word--|round-arched |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Of a building, architectural feature, etc.: having a semicircular arch or aches, especially in the Romanesque style.|Designating a style of architecture characterized by the use of such arches, especially the Romanesque.|--Examples--|
--Word--|round-arm |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|(of bowling) performed with an outward horizontal swing of the arm.|--Examples--|

appeared round the corner|Steven parked the car round the corner|if he didn't shut up he might get a clip round the ear|she went round the house and saw that all the windows were barred|the ship rounded the cape and sailed north|we'll round the weight up to the nearest kilo|the committee rounded down the figure|a lathe that rounded chair legs|her eyes rounded in dismay|the actor's uneven attempt to round the vowels of his midwestern twang|

--Word--|round-eared |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having round ears or ear-like appendages. In later use chiefly Zoology, in the names of mammals with rounded ears.|Designating a European willow, Salix aurita, which has persistent, ear-shaped, toothed stipules growing either side of the stem near the base of the leaves.|Designating a type of cap (or occasionally wig) fitting closely around the head and covering the ears, popular in the mid 18th cent. Now historical.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rounded |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having a smooth, curved surface.|Having a spherical shape.|Forming circular or elliptical shapes.|(of a vowel) pronounced with the lips narrowed and protruded.|Well developed in all aspects; complete and balanced.|--Examples--|rounded grey hills|his large, rounded stomach|his writing was firm and rounded|we should educate children to become rounded human beings|
--Word--|edge |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The outside limit of an object, area, or surface.|An area next to a steep drop.|The point immediately before something unpleasant or momentous occurs.|The sharpened side of the blade of a cutting implement or weapon.|The line along which two surfaces of a solid meet.|An intense, sharp, or striking quality.|A quality or factor which gives superiority over close rivals.|Provide with a border or edge.|Move or cause to move gradually or furtively in a particular direction.|Give an intense or sharp quality to.|Strike (the ball) with the edge of the bat; strike a ball delivered by (the bowler) with the edge of the bat.|Ski with one's weight on the edges of one's skis.|--Examples--|a willow tree at the water's edge|she perched on the edge of a desk|the cliff edge|the economy was teetering on the edge of recession|a knife with a razor-sharp edge|a flamenco singer brings a primitive edge to the music|there was an edge of menace in his voice|his cars have the edge over his rivals'|the pool is edged with paving|she tried to edge away from him|Hazel quietly edged him away from the others|the bitterness that edged her voice|he edged a ball into his pad|Haynes edged to slip|you will be edging early, controlling a parallel turn|

--Word--|roundel |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A small disc, especially a decorative medallion.|A picture or pattern contained in a circle.|A plain filled circle as a charge (often with a special name according to colour).|A circular identifying mark painted on military aircraft, as, for example, the red, white, and blue of the RAF.|A short poem consisting of three stanzas of three lines each, rhyming alternately, with the opening words repeated as a refrain after the first and third stanzas. The form, a variant of the rondeau, was developed by Swinburne.|--Examples--|the calendar is painted with roundels of the Labours of the Months|

--Word--|round |--Type--|adjective, noun, adverb, preposition, verb|--Meanings--|Shaped like a circle or cylinder.|Having a curved shape like part of the circumference of a circle.|(of a person's shoulders) bent forward from the line of the back.|Shaped like a sphere.|(of a person's body) plump.|Having a curved surface with no sharp projections.|(of a voice) rich and mellow; not harsh.|(of a number) expressed in convenient units rather than exactly, for example to the nearest whole number or multiple of ten.|Used to show that a figure has been completely and exactly reached.|(of a sum of money) considerable.|Not omitting or disguising anything; frank.|A circular piece of something.|A thick disc of beef cut from the haunch as a joint.|An act of visiting a number of people or places in turn.|A regular tour of inspection in which the well-being of those visited is checked.|A journey along a fixed route delivering goods as part of one's job or a job involving such journeys.|Each of a sequence of sessions in a process, typically characterized by development between one session and another.|A division of a contest such as a boxing or wrestling match.|Each of a succession of stages in a competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated.|An act of playing all the holes in a golf course once.|A regularly recurring sequence of activities.|A set of drinks bought for all the members of a group, typically as part of a sequence in which each member in turn buys such a set.|A song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts, each singing the same theme but starting one after another, at the same pitch or in octaves; a simple canon.|A slice of bread.|The quantity of sandwiches made from two slices of bread.|The amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot.|A fixed number of arrows shot from a fixed distance.|So as to rotate or cause rotation; with circular motion.|So as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular centre.|So as to reach everyone in a particular group or area.|So as to rotate and face in the opposite direction.|So as to lead in another direction.|Used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items.|Used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events.|So as to surround someone or something.|Used in stating the girth of something.|So as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving to the other side of something.|Used to convey an ability to navigate or orientate oneself.|Used to convey the idea of visiting someone else.|Used to suggest idle and purposeless motion or activity.|So as to give support and companionship.|On every side of (a focal point)|(of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focus.|So as to encircle (someone or something)|(of a person's arm or arms) partially encircling (another person) as a gesture of affection.|Following an approximately circular route past (a corner or obstacle)|On the other side of (a corner or obstacle)|So as to hit (something) in passing.|So as to cover or take in the whole area of (a place)|Pass and go round (something) so as to move on in a changed direction.|Alter (a number) to one less exact but more convenient for calculations.|Give a round shape to.|Become circular in shape.|Pronounce (a vowel) with the lips narrowed and protruded.|--Examples--|she was seated at a small, round table|round brackets|a round glass ball|the grapes are small and round|he could move --Word--|roundly |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|In a vehement or emphatic manner.|So thoroughly as to leave no doubt.|Too plainly for politeness; bluntly.|So as to form a circular or roughly circular shape.|--Examples--|the latest attacks have been roundly condemned by campaigners for peace|the army was roundly beaten|she told him roundly to get to the point|he was a middle-aged, roundly built man|

--Word--|round-mouthed |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Having, characterized by, or produced by a round-shaped mouth. Also figurative: elegant, sonorous.|Zoology. Of a gastropod mollusc: having a shell with a round mouth; specifically designating a terrestrial European snail, Pomatias elegans (family Pomatiidae), which has a thick-walled and somewhat conical shell with a calcified operculum.|Of an object: having a round opening, or a rounded end or edge.|--Examples--|

--Word--|round-off |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The act of rounding something off. Compare to round off.|An instance of rounding a number off; = rounding.|Gymnastics. An exercise similar to a cartwheel, in which the gymnast closes his or her legs on reaching a vertical position, and executes a quarter turn to land with the back to the direction of travel. Also called Arab spring, (occasionally) Arabian spring.|--Examples--|

--Word--|round |--Type--|adjective, noun, adverb, preposition, verb|--Meanings--|Shaped like a circle or cylinder.|Having a curved shape like part of the circumference of a circle.|(of a person's shoulders) bent forward from the line of the back.|Shaped like a sphere.|(of a person's body) plump.|Having a curved surface with no sharp projections.|(of a voice) rich and mellow; not harsh.|(of a number) expressed in convenient units rather than exactly, for example to the nearest whole number or multiple of ten.|Used to show that a figure has been completely and exactly reached.|(of a sum of money) considerable.|Not omitting or disguising anything; frank.|A circular piece of something.|A thick disc of beef cut from the haunch as a joint.|An act of visiting a number of people or places in turn.|A regular tour of inspection in which the well-being of those visited is checked.|A journey along a fixed route delivering goods as part of one's job or a job involving such journeys.|Each of a sequence of sessions in a process, typically characterized by development between one session and another.|A division of a contest such as a boxing or wrestling match.|Each of a succession of stages in a competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated.|An act of playing all the holes in a golf course once.|A regularly recurring sequence of activities.|A set of drinks bought for all the members of a group, typically as part of a sequence in which each member in turn buys such a set.|A song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts, each singing the same theme but starting one after another, at the same pitch or in octaves; a simple canon.|A slice of bread.|The quantity of sandwiches made from two slices of bread.|The amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot.|A fixed number of arrows shot from a fixed distance.|So as to rotate or cause rotation; with circular motion.|So as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular centre.|So as to reach everyone in a particular group or area.|So as to rotate and face in the opposite direction.|So as to lead in another direction.|Used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items.|Used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events.|So as to surround someone or something.|Used in stating the girth of something.|So as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving to the other side of something.|Used to convey an ability to navigate or orientate oneself.|Used to convey the idea of visiting someone else.|Used to suggest idle and purposeless motion or activity.|So as to give support and companionship.|On every side of (a focal point)|(of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focus.|So as to encircle (someone or something)|(of a person's arm or arms) partially encircling (another person) as a gesture of affection.|Following an approximately circular route past (a corner or obstacle)|On the other side of (a corner or obstacle)|So as to hit (something) in passing.|So as to cover or take in the whole area of (a place)|Pass and go round (something) so as to move on in a changed direction.|Alter (a number) to one less exact but more convenient for calculations.|Give a round shape to.|Become circular in shape.|Pronounce (a vowel) with the lips narrowed and protruded.|--Examples--|she was seated at a small, round table|round brackets|a round glass ball|the grapes are small and round|he could move quickly despite his round physique|the boulders look round and smooth|his rich, round voice went down well with the listeners|the size of the fleet is given in round numbers|the batsman made a round 100|a round dozen|his business is worth a round sum to me|she berated him in good round terms|cut the pastry into rounds|she did the rounds of her family to say goodbye|the doctor is just making his rounds in the wards|I did a newspaper round|the two sides held three rounds of talks|the FA Cup first round|Eileen enjoys the occasional round of golf|their lives were a daily round of housework and laundry|it's my round|two rounds of toast|the gun can fire 30 rounds a second|a plane circled round overhead|she turned her glass round and round|she paused to glance round admiringly at the décor|he passed round a newspaper cutting|he swung round to face her|it was the last house before the road curved round|the picture shows the pieces the wrong way round|it was he who was attacking her, not the other way round|everyone crowded round|a pool with banks all the way round|the trunk is nine feet round|he made his way round to the back of the building|they went the long way round by the main road|I like pupils to find their own way round|why don't you come round to my flat?|he was driving round aimlessly|if one girl is distraught the others will rally round|the area round the school|with shifting sands all round me|the text is built round real practical examples|he wrapped the blanket round him|she drew a red circle round his name|Angus put an arm round Flora and kissed her|a bus appeared round the corner|Steven parked the car round the corner|if he didn't shut up he might get a clip round the ear|she went round the house and saw that all the windows were barred|the ship rounded the cape and sailed north|we'll round the weight up to the nearest kilo|the committee rounded down the figure|a lathe that rounded chair legs|her eyes rounded in dismay|the actor's uneven attempt to round the vowels of his midwestern twang|

--Word--|Rousseau, Théodore |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1812–67), French painter; full name Pierre Étienne Théodore Rousseau. A leading landscapist of the Barbizon School, his works typically depict the scenery and changing light effects of the forest of Fontainebleau, for example Under the Birches, Evening (1842–4).|--Examples--|

--Word--|Roussillon |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A former province of southern France, on the border with Spain in the eastern Pyrenees, now part of Languedoc-Roussillon. Part of Spain until 1659, Roussillon retains many of its Spanish characteristics and traditions and Catalan is widely spoken.|--Examples--|

--Word--|routinary |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Characterized by an adherence to routine; of or relating to routine; mechanical, unvaried; (of a person) that acts according to routine.|--Examples--|
--Word--|routine |--Type--|noun, adjective, verb|--Meanings--|A sequence of actions regularly followed.|A set sequence in a performance such as a dance or comedy act.|A sequence of instructions for performing a task that forms a program or a distinct part of one.|Performed as part of a regular procedure rather than for a special reason.|Organize according to a routine.|--Examples--|I settled down into a routine of work and sleep|as a matter of routine a report will be sent to the director|he was trying to persuade her to have a tap routine in the play|the Ministry insisted that this was just a routine annual drill|all had been routined with smoothness|
--Word--|routineer |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who acts according to routine; specifically one who adheres to an established or prescribed way of doing something, without recourse to innovation or imagination (frequently depreciative).|--Examples--|
--Word--|routinely |--Type--|adverb|--Meanings--|As part of a regular procedure rather than for a special reason.|Frequently and without proper consideration of the consequences.|--Examples--|large-scale producers routinely vaccinate their birds against the disease|owners routinely flout local laws about restraining and picking up after their pets|
--Word--|routineness |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Dull regularity of events or actions.|--Examples--|the routineness of life|

--Word--|rub |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Apply firm pressure to the surface of (something), using a repeated back and forth motion.|Move (one's hand, a cloth, or another object) back and forth against a surface.|Apply (ointment, polish, or a similar substance) with a back and forth motion.|Make dry, clean, or smooth by rubbing.|Work an ingredient into (a mixture) by breaking and blending it with firm movements of one's fingers.|Reproduce the design of (a sepulchral brass or a stone) by rubbing paper laid on it with coloured wax, pencil, or chalk, etc.|(with reference to two things) move or cause to move to and fro against each other with a certain amount of friction.|(of shoes or other hard items in contact with the skin) cause pain through friction.|(of a bowl) be slowed or diverted by the unevenness of the ground.|An act of rubbing.|An ointment designed to be rubbed on the skin to ease pain.|The central problem or difficulty in a situation.|(in bowling) an uneven patch of ground that impedes or diverts a bowl.|--Examples--|she rubbed her arm, where she had a large bruise|he rubbed at the earth on his jeans|he rubbed a finger round the rim of his mug|she took out her suncream and rubbed some on her nose|she found a towel and began rubbing her hair|I rubbed myself dry|sift the flour into a bowl and rub in the fat|he was rubbing an old brass|many insects make noises by rubbing parts of their bodies together|the ice breaks into small floes that rub against each other|badly fitting shoes can rub painfully|she pulled out a towel and gave her head a quick rub|a muscle rub|that was the rub—she had not cared enough|

--Word--|rubicon |--Type--|noun, verb, proper noun|--Meanings--|(in piquet) an act of winning a game against an opponent whose total score is less than 100, in which case the loser's score is added to rather than subtracted from the winner's.|Score a rubicon against (one's opponent).|A stream in north-eastern Italy which marked the ancient boundary between Italy and Cisalpine Gaul. Julius Caesar led his army across it into Italy in 49 BC, breaking the law forbidding a general to lead an army out of his province, and so committing himself to war against the Senate and Pompey. The ensuing civil war resulted in victory for Caesar after three years.|A point of no return.|--Examples--|on the way to political union we are now crossing the Rubicon|
--Word--|rubicon |--Type--|noun, verb, proper noun|--Meanings--|(in piquet) an act of winning a game against an opponent whose total score is less than 100, in which case the loser's score is added to rather than subtracted from the winner's.|Score a rubicon against (one's opponent).|A stream in north-eastern Italy which marked the ancient boundary between Italy and Cisalpine Gaul. Julius Caesar led his army across it into Italy in 49 BC, breaking the law forbidding a general to lead an army out of his province, and so committing himself to war against the Senate and Pompey. --Word--|rub |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Apply firm pressure to the surface of (something), using a repeated back and forth motion.|Move (one's hand, a cloth, or another object) back and forth against a surface.|Apply (ointment, polish, or a similar substance) with a back and forth motion.|Make dry, clean, or smooth by rubbing.|Work an ingredient into (a mixture) by breaking and blending it with firm movements of one's fingers.|Reproduce the design of (a sepulchral brass or a stone) by rubbing paper laid on it with coloured wax, pencil, or chalk, etc.|(with reference to two things) move or cause to move to and fro against each other with a certain amount of friction.|(of shoes or other hard items in contact with the skin) cause pain through friction.|(of a bowl) be slowed or diverted by the unevenness of the ground.|An act of rubbing.|An ointment designed to be rubbed on the skin to ease pain.|The central problem or difficulty in a situation.|(in bowling) an uneven patch of ground that impedes or diverts a bowl.|--Examples--|she rubbed her arm, where she had a large bruise|he rubbed at the earth on his jeans|he rubbed a finger round the rim of his mug|she took out her suncream and rubbed some on her nose|she found a towel and began rubbing her hair|I rubbed myself dry|sift the flour into a bowl and rub in the fat|he was rubbing an old brass|many insects make noises by rubbing parts of their bodies together|the ice breaks into small floes that rub against each other|badly fitting shoes can rub painfully|she pulled out a towel and gave her head a quick rub|a muscle rub|that was the rub—she had not cared enough|

--Word--|rude |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Offensively impolite or bad-mannered.|Referring to a taboo subject such as sex in a way considered embarrassing or offensive.|Having a startling abruptness.|Vigorous or hearty.|Roughly made or done; lacking sophistication.|Ignorant and uneducated.|--Examples--|she had been rude to her boss|he is a rude and arrogant bully|it's rude to talk about people right in front of them|Graham giggled at every rude joke|the war came as a very rude awakening|Isabel had always been in rude health|a rude coffin|the new religion was first promulgated by rude men|

--Word--|Kipling, Rudyard |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1865–1936), British novelist, short-story writer, and poet; full name Joseph Rudyard Kipling. Born in India, he is known for his poems, such as If and Gunga Din and his children's tales, notably The Jungle Book (1894) and the Just So Stories (1902). Nobel Prize for Literature (1907).|--Examples--|

--Word--|Rudolph, Wilma |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1940–94), US track athlete; full name Wilma Glodean Rudolph. A runner, she was the first American woman to win three track and field gold medals in one Olympics, 1960.|--Examples--|
--Word--|Rudolphine |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|Designating a series of astronomical calculations, based on the observational data of Tycho Brahe, published by Johannes Kepler in 1627; especially in Rudolphine Tables.|--Examples--|
--Word--|Rudra |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(in the Rig Veda) a Vedic minor god, associated with the storm, father of the Maruts.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rue |--Type--|verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|Bitterly regret (something one has done or allowed to happen) and wish it undone.|Repentance; regret.|Compassion; pity.|A perennial evergreen shrub with bitter strong-scented lobed leaves which are used in herbal medicine.|Used in names of other plants that resemble rue, especially in leaf shape, e.g. goat's rue, meadow rue, and wall rue.|--Examples--|Ferguson will rue the day he turned down that offer|she might live to rue this impetuous decision|with rue my heart is laden|tears of pitying rue|
--Word--|rue |--Type--|verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|Bitterly regret (something one has done or allowed to happen) and wish it undone.|Repentance; regret.|Compassion; pity.|A perennial evergreen shrub with bitter strong-scented lobed leaves which are used in herbal medicine.|Used in names of other plants that resemble rue, especially in leaf shape, e.g. goat's rue, meadow rue, and wall rue.|--Examples--|Ferguson will rue the day he turned down that offer|she might live to rue this impetuous decision|with rue my heart is laden|tears of pitying rue|

--Word--|ruel-bone |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Ivory, probably from the tusk of a walrus or narwhal; = ruel; (also) a piece of ivory. Hence occasionally as adjective: made of this. Now archaic and literary.|--Examples--|
--Word--|rue |--Type--|verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|Bitterly regret (something one has done or allowed to happen) and wish it undone.|Repentance; regret.|Compassion; pity.|A perennial evergreen shrub with bitter strong-scented lobed leaves which are used in herbal medicine.|Used in names of other plants that resemble rue, especially in leaf shape, e.g. goat's rue, meadow rue, and wall rue.|--Examples--|Ferguson will rue the day he turned down that offer|she might live to rue this impetuous decision|with rue my heart is laden|tears of pitying rue|
--Word--|ruelle |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The passage or space between a bed and the wall; (hence also) the side or part of a bed next to the wall. Now historical.|This space, or the area around the bed generally, where a distinguished person received favoured guests while in bed, especially where (in 17th and 18th cent. France) a lady of fashion held morning receptions. So in extended use: an audience or reception of this kind; a (social or literary) gathering in a ruelle. Now historical.|In France or French-speaking regions: a small street; a lane, alley.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruellia |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Any of numerous flowering plants comprising the genus Ruellia (family Acanthaceae), chiefly native to tropical regions of Asia and the Americas but commonly cultivated elsewhere as ornamentals for their showy funnel-shaped flowers. Also (in form Ruellia): the genus itself.|--Examples--|

--Word--|ruff |--Type--|noun, noun, verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|A projecting starched frill worn round the neck, characteristic of Elizabethan and Jacobean costume.|A projecting or conspicuously coloured ring of feathers or hair round the neck of a bird or mammal.|A pigeon of a domestic breed with a ruff of feathers on its neck.|A North Eurasian wading bird, the male of which has a large variously coloured ruff and ear tufts in the breeding season, used in display.|An edible marine fish of Australian inshore waters that is related to the Australian salmon.|(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump in a trick which was led in a different suit.|Play a trump on (a card in another suit)|An act of ruffing or opportunity to ruff.|One of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of a single note preceded by either two grace notes played with the other stick (double-stroke ruff or drag) or three grace notes played with alternating sticks (four-stroke ruff).|--Examples--|an Elizabethan ruff|a ruff of long pointed feathers|my nape stirred like the ruff of a dog in a thunderstorm|declarer ruffed and then led a heart|South ruffs a low spade|he gave his partner a spade ruff|
--Word--|ruffer |--Type--|noun, noun|--Meanings--|A person who ruffs at cards. rare.|Chiefly Whist and Bridge. A card that ruffs or trumps another.|A device for ruffing flax, consisting of a board studded with spikes or teeth.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruff |--Type--|noun, noun, verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|A projecting starched frill worn round the neck, characteristic of Elizabethan and Jacobean costume.|A projecting or conspicuously coloured ring of feathers or hair round the neck of a bird or mammal.|A pigeon of a domestic breed with a ruff of feathers on its neck.|A North Eurasian wading bird, the male of which has a large variously coloured ruff and ear tufts in the breeding season, used in display.|An edible marine fish of Australian inshore waters that is related to the Australian salmon.|(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump in a trick which was led in a different suit.|Play a trump on (a card in another suit)|An act of ruffing or opportunity to ruff.|One of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of a single note preceded by either two grace notes played with the other stick (double-stroke ruff or drag) or three grace notes played with alternating sticks (four-stroke ruff).|--Examples--|an Elizabethan ruff|a ruff of long pointed feathers|my nape stirred like the ruff of a dog in a thunderstorm|declarer ruffed and then led a heart|South ruffs a low spade|he gave his partner a spade ruff|

--Word--|ruff |--Type--|noun, noun, verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|A projecting starched frill worn round the neck, characteristic of Elizabethan and Jacobean costume.|A projecting or conspicuously coloured ring of feathers or hair round the neck of a bird or mammal.|A pigeon of a domestic breed with a ruff of feathers on its neck.|A North Eurasian wading bird, the male of which has a large variously coloured ruff and ear tufts in the breeding season, used in display.|An edible marine fish of Australian inshore waters that is related to the Australian salmon.|(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump in a trick which was led in a different suit.|Play a trump on (a card in another suit)|An act of ruffing or opportunity to ruff.|One of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of a single note preceded by either two grace notes played with the other stick (double-stroke ruff or drag) or three grace notes played with alternating sticks (four-stroke ruff).|--Examples--|an Elizabethan ruff|a ruff of long pointed feathers|my nape stirred like the ruff of a dog in a thunderstorm|declarer ruffed and then led a heart|South ruffs a low spade|he gave his partner a spade ruff|
--Word--|ruffy |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A rough light made from a rag wick dipped in tallow.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruffle |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Disorder or disarrange (someone's hair), typically by running one's hands through it.|(of a bird) erect (its feathers) in anger or display.|Disturb the smoothness or tranquillity of.|Disconcert or upset the composure of (someone)|Ornament with or gather into a frill.|An ornamental gathered or goffered frill of lace or other cloth on a garment, especially around the wrist or neck.|A vibrating drum beat.|--Examples--|he ruffled her hair affectionately|they warbled incessantly, their throat feathers ruffled|the evening breeze ruffled the surface of the pond in the yard|Lancaster had been ruffled by her questions|a blouse with a high ruffled neck|

--Word--|rugby |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A team game played with an oval ball that may be kicked, carried, and passed from hand to hand. Points are scored by grounding the ball behind the opponents' goal line (thereby scoring a try) or by kicking it between the two posts and over the crossbar of the opponents' goal.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ruhr |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|A region of coal mining and heavy industry in North Rhine-Westphalia, western Germany. It is named after the River Ruhr, which flows through it, meeting the River Rhine near Duisburg. The Ruhr was occupied by French troops 1923–4, after Germany defaulted on war reparation payments.|--Examples--|
--Word--|Ruy Lopez |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An opening in which White's third move uses the king's bishop to attack the black knight on the square c6 which defends the pawn on e5.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruin |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The physical destruction or disintegration of something or the state of disintegrating or being destroyed.|The remains of a building, typically an old one that has suffered much damage or disintegration.|The disastrous disintegration of someone's life.|The complete loss of one's money and other assets.|Something that causes the disintegration of a person's life or the complete loss of their assets.|Reduce (a building or place) to a state of decay, collapse, or disintegration.|Cause great and usually irreparable damage or harm to; have a disastrous effect on.|Reduce to a state of poverty.|Fall headlong or with a crash.|--Examples--|a large white house falling into gentle ruin|the ruins of the castle|the church is a ruin now|the ruin and heartbreak wrought by alcohol, divorce, and violence|the financial cost could mean ruin|they don't know how to say no, and that's been their ruin|the castle was ruined when dynamite was used to demolish one of the corner towers|a noisy motorway has ruined village life|they were ruined by the highest interest rates this century|carriages go ruining over the brink from time to time|
--Word--|ruinable |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|That may be ruined; perishable.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruinate |--Type--|adjective, noun, verb|--Meanings--|In attributive use.|Chiefly Jamaican. Of land: exhausted and allowed to revert to the wild.|Chiefly Jamaican. Formerly cultivated land which has reverted to the wild; a tract of such land.|To reduce (a person) to a state of complete poverty; to deprive of moral or social standing. Also refl. Compare ruin. Now frequently regional.|To cause great and usually irreparable damage to (something). Compare ruin Now chiefly archaic and regional.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruinated |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|In attributive use.|In predicative use.|Irreparably damaged or spoilt; brought low. Compare ruinate. Now regional (chiefly Irish English).|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruinate |--Type--|adjective, noun, verb|--Meanings--|In attributive use.|Chiefly Jamaican. Of land: exhausted and allowed to revert to the wild.|Chiefly Jamaican. Formerly cultivated land which has reverted to the wild; a tract of such land.|To reduce (a person) to a state of complete poverty; to deprive of moral or social standing. Also refl. Compare ruin. Now frequently regional.|To cause great and usually irreparable damage to (something). Compare ruin Now chiefly archaic and regional.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruinating |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|That ruins someone or something; destructive. Now rare.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruination |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|The action or fact of ruining someone or something or of being ruined.|The state of being ruined.|--Examples--|commercial malpractice causes the ruination of thousands of people|the headquarters fell into ruination|

--Word--|ruinatious |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|That brings or tends to bring ruin; ruinous, disastrous.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruinator |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person who ruins someone or something.|--Examples--|
--Word--|ruin |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|The physical destruction or disintegration of something or the state of disintegrating or being destroyed.|The remains of a building, typically an old one that has suffered much damage or disintegration.|The disastrous disintegration of someone's life.|The complete loss of one's money and other assets.|Something that causes the disintegration of a person's life or the complete loss of their assets.|Reduce (a building or place) to a state of decay, collapse, or disintegration.|Cause great and usually irreparable damage or harm to; have a disastrous effect on.|Reduce to a state of poverty.|Fall headlong or with a crash.|--Examples--|a large white house falling into gentle ruin|the ruins of the castle|the church is a ruin now|the ruin and heartbreak wrought by alcohol, divorce, and violence|the financial cost could mean ruin|they don't know how to say no, and that's been their ruin|the castle was ruined when dynamite was used to demolish one of the corner towers|a noisy motorway has ruined village life|they were ruined by the highest interest rates this century|carriages go ruining over the brink from time to time|

--Word--|ruined |--Type--|adjective|--Meanings--|(of a building or place) reduced to a state of decay, collapse, or disintegration.|Having been irreparably damaged or harmed.|--Examples--|a ruined castle|his ruined career|the nation's ruined economy|

--Word--|rue |--Type--|verb, noun, noun|--Meanings--|Bitterly regret (something one has done or allowed to happen) and wish it undone.|Repentance; regret.|Compassion; pity.|A perennial evergreen shrub with bitter strong-scented lobed leaves which are used in herbal medicine.|Used in names of other plants that resemble rue, especially in leaf shape, e.g. goat's rue, meadow rue, and wall rue.|--Examples--|Ferguson will rue the day he turned down that offer|she might live to rue this impetuous decision|with rue my heart is laden|tears of pitying rue|

--Word--|rule |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|One of a set of explicit or understood regulations or principles governing conduct or procedure within a particular area of activity.|A principle that operates within a particular sphere of knowledge, describing or prescribing what is possible or allowable.|A code of practice and discipline for a religious order or community.|Control of or dominion over an area or people.|The normal or customary state of things.|A strip of wood or other rigid material used for measuring length or marking straight lines; a ruler.|A thin printed line or dash.|Exercise ultimate power or authority over (an area and its people)|(of a feeling) have a powerful and restricting influence on.|Be a dominant or powerful factor.|Be very good or the best.|(of a planet) have a particular influence over (a sign of the zodiac, house, etc.)|Pronounce authoritatively and legally to be the case.|Make parallel lines across (paper)|(of a price or a traded commodity with regard to its price) have a specified general level or strength.|--Examples--|the rules of cricket|those who did break the rules would be dealt with swiftly|the rules of grammar|the Rule of St Benedict|the revolution brought an end to British rule|such accidents are the exception rather than the rule|Latin America today is ruled by elected politicians|the period in which Spain ruled over Portugal|her whole life seemed to be ruled by fear|the black market rules supreme|Jackie tells me about Hanna's newest band, and says that it absolutely rules|the tenth House, ruled by Saturn and associated with Capricorn|an industrial tribunal ruled that he was unfairly dismissed from his job|rule the pages horizontally and print the information within the rules|in the jutes section Indus and Pak Jute ruled firm|

--Word--|rumble |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Make a continuous deep, resonant sound.|(especially of a large vehicle) move with a rumbling sound.|Utter in a deep, resonant voice.|(of a person's stomach) make a deep, resonant sound due to hunger.|(of a dispute) continue in a persistent but low-key way.|Discover (an illicit activity or its perpetrator)|Take part in a street fight between gangs or large groups.|A continuous deep, resonant sound like distant thunder.|A street fight between gangs or large groups.|--Examples--|thunder rumbled, lightning flickered|heavy lorries rumbled through the streets|the man's low voice rumbled an instruction|as she passed the buffet car her stomach rumbled|the debate about television replays rumbles on|it wouldn't need a genius to rumble my little game|the five of them rumbled with the men in the other car|the continuous rumble of traffic|there were of rumbles of discontent from small retailers|a rumble between two gangs of street thugs|

--Word--|runner |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A person that runs, especially in a specified way.|A person who runs competitively as a sport or hobby.|A horse that runs in a particular race.|A vehicle or machine that operates in a satisfactory or specified way.|A contender for a job or position.|An idea that has a chance of being accepted; a practical suggestion.|A person who runs between the wickets for an injured batsman.|A messenger, collector, or agent for a bank, bookmaker, or similar.|An orderly in the army.|A freelance antiques dealer.|A person who smuggles specified goods into or out of a country or area.|A rod, groove, or blade on which something slides.|Each of the long pieces on the underside of a sledge that forms the contact in sliding.|A roller for moving a heavy article.|A ring capable of slipping or sliding along a strap or rod or through which something may be passed or drawn.|A rope in a single block with one end round a tackle block and the other having a hook.|A shoot, typically leafless, which grows from the base of a plant along the surface of the ground and can take root at points along its length.|A plant that spreads by means of runners.|A twining plant.|A long, narrow rug or strip of carpet, especially for a hall or stairway.|A revolving millstone.|A police officer.|A fast-swimming fish of the jack family, occurring in tropical seas.|--Examples--|Mary was a fast runner|a 400 metres runner|there were only four runners|the van was a good and reliable runner|I am one among fifty runners for the job|the original runners for the Booker Prize|trying to determine whether a tax on books is a runner|he came in to bat with a runner|runners who spend their time looking for good buys|a gun-runner|the vegetable baskets were on runners|it's not always easy to find strawberry runners with good strong roots|a faded runner held in place with brass stair rods|

The Royalist leader of cavalry, he initially won a series of victories, but was defeated by Parliamentarian forces at Marston Moor (1644) and Naseby (1645).|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ruppia |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|A plant of the genus Ruppia, the sole member of the family Ruppiaceae (formerly included in the pondweed family, Potamogetonaceae), comprising plants found in shallow brackish or saline water, having thread-like leaves with small flowers borne on long, frequently coiled stems which float on the surface of the water at maturity, especially (more fully sea ruppia) the wigeon-grass, R. maritima.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rupture |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|(especially of a pipe or container, or bodily part such as an organ or membrane) break or burst suddenly.|Cause to break or burst suddenly.|Suffer an abdominal hernia.|Breach or disturb (a harmonious feeling or situation)|An instance of breaking or bursting suddenly and completely.|An abdominal hernia.|A breach of a harmonious relationship.|--Examples--|if the main artery ruptures he could die|the impact ruptured both fuel tanks|one of the boys was ruptured and needed to be fitted with a truss|once trust and confidence has been ruptured it can be difficult to regain|a small hairline crack could develop into a rupture|the patient died after rupture of an aneurysm|the rupture with his father would never be healed|

--Word--|ruscus |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|Any of various plants constituting the chiefly Eurasian genus Ruscus (family Ruscaceae (formerly included in the Liliaceae)), of evergreen shrubs with flat, stiff, pointed shoots (cladophylls) that resemble leaves; especially butcher's broom, R. aculeatus, which has pale green flowers and is commonly grown in gardens. In later use also (in form Ruscus): the genus itself.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rush |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Move with urgent haste.|(of air or a liquid) flow strongly.|Act with great haste.|Force (someone) to act hastily.|Take (someone) somewhere with great haste.|Deliver (something) quickly to (someone)|Produce and distribute something very quickly.|Deal with (something) hurriedly.|Dash towards (someone or something) in an attempt to attack or capture.|Advance towards (an opposing player, especially the quarterback)|Run from scrimmage with the ball.|Entertain (a new student) in order to assess suitability for membership of a college fraternity or sorority.|(of a student) visit (a college fraternity or sorority) with a view to joining it.|Make (a customer) pay a particular amount, especially an excessive one.|A sudden quick movement towards something, typically by a number of people.|A sudden flow or flood.|A flurry of hasty activity.|A sudden strong demand for a commodity.|A sudden intense feeling.|A sudden thrill or feeling of euphoria such as experienced after taking certain drugs.|An act of advancing forward, especially towards the quarterback.|The first prints made of a film after a period of shooting.|--Examples--|Oliver rushed after her|I rushed outside and hailed a taxi|the water rushed in through the great oaken gates|as soon as the campaign started they rushed into action|shoppers rushed to buy computers|I don't want to rush you into something|an ambulance was waiting to rush him to hospital|we'll rush you a copy at once|a rewritten textbook was rushed out last autumn|panic measures were rushed through parliament|to rush the bank and fire willy-nilly could be disastrous for everyone|a linebacker who was gifted in rushing the quarterback|he rushed for 100 yards on 22 carries|athletics and fraternity rushing were much more important than anything that happened to you in the classroom|he rushed three fraternities|how much did they rush you for this heap?|They rushed you, all right! It's not worth a penny more than £120|there was a rush for the door|she felt a rush of cold air|the pre-Christmas rush|a rush job|there's been a rush onthe Western News because of the murder|Mark felt a rush of anger|users experience a rush|after the shoot the agency team will see the rushes|

--Word--|rushbearing |--Type--|noun|--Meanings--|An annual ceremony performed chiefly in parts of northern England, in which rushes and garlands are carried to a church and used to strew the floor or decorate the walls.|--Examples--|

--Word--|Ruskin, John |--Type--|proper noun|--Meanings--|(1819–1900), English art and social critic. His prolific writings on art and architecture include Modern Painters (five volumes, 1843–60), The Seven Lamps of Architecture (1849), and The Stones of Venice (three volumes, 1851–3). After 1860 he devoted himself to social and economic reform, campaigning for the recovery of medieval piety and Christian ideals and against the scientific advances of his times.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rustic |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Relating to the countryside; rural.|Having a simplicity and charm that is considered typical of the countryside.|Lacking the sophistication of the city; backward and provincial.|Made in a plain and simple fashion.|Made of untrimmed branches or rough timber.|(of masonry) having a rough-hewn or roughened surface or deeply sunk joints.|Denoting freely formed lettering, especially a relatively informal style of handwritten Roman capital letter.|An unsophisticated country person.|A small brownish European moth.|--Examples--|the unblemished charm of rustic life has been a perennial source of inspiration for the painter|bare plaster walls and terracotta floor give a rustic feel|you are a rustic halfwit|rustic pottery|a rustic oak bench|a rustic bridge|rustic capitals were much easier to form|they paused to watch the rustics dance and carouse|
--Word--|rustical |--Type--|adjective, noun|--Meanings--|Of a thing: characteristic of the countryside or country life; of a type or style appropriate to the country; especially plain, simple; crude.|Of speech, writing, behaviour, etc.: characteristic or typical of country people; especially (depreciative) unrefined, vulgar.|Of a person: boorish; unsophisticated; = rustic. Now rare.|A person who lives in the countryside (typically implying ignorance or lack of sophistication); a yokel; = rustic. Now archaic and rare.|--Examples--|

--Word--|rustle |--Type--|verb, noun|--Meanings--|Make a soft, muffled crackling sound like that caused by the movement of dry leaves or paper.|Move with a rustling sound.|Cause (something) to make a rustling sound.|Round up and steal (cattle, horses, or sheep)|Move or act quickly or energetically; hustle.|A soft, muffled crackling sound like that made by the movement of dry leaves or paper.|rustle something up|Produce something quickly when it is needed.|--Examples--|she came closer, her skirt swaying and rustling|a nurse rustled in|Dolly rustled the paper irritably|a murdered rancher whose cattle were being rustled|horse rustling is a growing problem|rustle around the kitchen, see what there is|there was a rustle in the undergrowth behind her|see if you can rustle up a cup of tea for Paula and me, please|

--Word--|rust |--Type--|noun, verb|--Meanings--|A reddish- or yellowish-brown flaking coating of iron oxide that is formed on iron or steel by oxidation, especially in the presence of moisture.|A fungal disease of plants which results in reddish or brownish patches.|A reddish-brown colour.|Be affected with rust.|--Examples--|paint protects your car from rust|the MPs are here to scrape the rust off the derelict machinery of government|her rust-coloured coat|the blades had rusted away|

In 1795, he was appointed US chief justice by President Washington and served for a short time but was ultimately rejected by the US Senate.|--Examples--|
